Ms. ___ is a ___ RH F with PMHx of HTN, HLD, DM, breast
cancer s/p L mastectomy who presents to ___ ED with acute on

her husband and daughter who provide the below history.
Mr. ___ was in her usual state of health until ___ of
this year. In ___ there were several significant social
stressors that appeared to be causing her a great deal of
anxiety. She also began sleeping much less, around ___ hours per
night. Around the same time, she began experiencing episodes of
confusion and difficulty making simple decision. The family
stresses that her cognition was very fluctuant - "she has good
days and bad days, sometime good and bad in the same day." Early
in her course, Ms. ___ seemed to be aware of her deficits -
she complained of confusion, anxiety, and had a premonition of
when she was going to worsen ("A fog is coming in").
For her complaints, she was evaluated by Dr. ___ in behavior
health and was given citalopram and clonazepam for anxiety.
Despite this, she continued to worsen - becoming more confused
and agitated, though with apparently preserved awareness of her
deficits. Her family states that during her periods of lucidity,
Ms. ___ would say "I need help."
On ___, she called her outpatient psych counselor to
request admission to inpatient psychiatry "because she was 
afraid
and could not function at home." She was admitted to ___ on ___ to psychiatry. During her admission, she 
was
not seen by neurology. She did have an MRI without contrast 
which
showed atrophy and white matter disease "greater than expected
for age." She was weaned off of her clonazepam during that
admission. 
Ms. ___ was discharged home on ___, and her family
reports that initially she seemed much better. She called her
son, and had full coherent conversations with her family 
members.
On ___, however, she had an acute worsening with new urinary
incontinence, gait unsteadiness, jerking movements, and
difficulty speaking. Her affect was also odd, laughing at
everything her husband said even when discussing serious
subjects. Her speech has continued to worsen to the point that
today she is barely able to get any words out at all. She is 
also
increasingly confused and agitated, pulling at her lines and
interfering with cares.

recommended that she go to ___ ED for neurological evaluation
and likely admission.

fevers,

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___

___ was a pleasure having you here at the ___ 
___.  You were admitted here after you were thought 
to be more confused.  The neurology team evaluated you and you 
had EEG, lumbar puncture studies and CT head studies which were 
all non-revealing for any pathology which may have caused your 
symptoms.  The psychiatry team thought that this may have been a 
result of your new medication called citalopram.  This 
medication was discontinued and you were managed with a group of 
medications called 'benzodiazepines' which helped your symptoms.

done which revealed clots in both lungs.  You were started on an 
intravenous blood thinner for these called heparin and 
eventually switched over to xarelto.  You should have 15mg twice

Name: ___ Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: M Service: SURGERY Allergies: lisinopril / Pineapple Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Failure to thrive Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: ___ EGD History of Present Illness: The patient is a ___ man who developed obstructive jaundice in ___. An ERCP at that time demonstrated a 2-cm distal biliary stricture which was stented; brushings were nondiagnostic. A subsequent MRI reported a 3.6-cm pancreatic head mass but given that multiple biopsy procedures since then have been non-diagnostic and the patient's persistently elevated serum IgG4 (340 and 498) he was started on steroids for autoimmune pancreatitis. The repeat CT scan three and a half weeks after starting steroids showed that the pancreatic body and tail were atrophic, the pancreatic duct was dilated and there was a solid lesion in the pancreatic head which appeared to involve the SMV. There were also significant new inflammatory changes anterior to the duodenum arising from the uncinate process and a pseudocyst which incorporated the right colic artery and vein. The case was discussed in the ___ Multidisciplinary Conference and the patient is being admitted today for placement of a Nasojejunal tube to maximize pancreatic rest and resolution of inflammation. The patient will also receive pain and nutritional consults for his intractable pain and weight loss (upto 40 lbs in the past two months, respectively. Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum ___ 09:56AM URINE COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 09:56AM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-POS PROTEIN-TR GLUCOSE->1000 KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.5 LEUK-TR ___ 09:56AM URINE RBC-0 WBC-6* BACTERIA-FEW YEAST-NONE EPI-0 ___ 09:56AM URINE MUCOUS-RARE Brief Hospital Course: The patient with autoimmune pancreatitis was admitted to the HPB Surgical Service for placement of NJ tube and initiation of tubefeeds secondary to failure to thrive at home. The NJ tube was placed on ___ and CRX confirmed NJ tube location in the stomach. Patient failed two fluorography attempts to advance the NJ tube into the jejunum. On ___ the patient underwent EGD and the NJ tube was successfully advanced beyond the ___ portion of the duodenum. The patient was hemodynamically stable. Neuro/Chronic pain: The patient was started on PO Oxycontin and Percocet per Chronic Pain service secondary to his poorly controlled chronic pain. His pain was well controlled on this regimen. He was discharged on PO MS ___ and Percocet for breakthrough pain. Oxycontin not covered by patient insurance. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout the hospitalization. GI/GU/FEN: Patient was given a clear liquid diet prior to his NJ tube placement. After the NJ was advanced, the patient was started on tubefeeds. His tube feedings were advanced to goal and started to cycle. The patient initially experienced diarrhea upon cycling of his tube feeds, but was tolerating them upon discharge. Home service was arranged prior to discharge. ID: On admission, the patient complained of burning with urination, and a UA and urine cultures were sent. Patient was started on PO Cipro x 3 days after UA returned positive for elevated WBC. Cultures were positive for Klebsiella sensitive to Cipro. Prior to discharge, the patient's renal symptoms had resolved. Endocrine: Patient has a history of type II DM and was on Metformin 1000 mg BID, as well as insulin, at home. While inpatient, he was noticed to have elevated blood sugars and ___ Diabetic service was called for consult. ___ recommendation were followed. Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined routinely; no transfusions were required. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. He was also encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating tube feed at goal, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled upon discharge. Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT
Mrs ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of multiple 
myeloma s/p autologous transplant day 276 on revlamid who 
presented from clinic with fevers, cough and fatigue found to 
have RLL penumonia.

ACUTE ISSUES
# Pneumonia: Mrs ___ was initially started on vancomycin 
and cefepime. Her home revlamid was held. As she continued to be 
febrile after 48 hours of coverage, azithromycin was added and a 
CT chest was obtained. CT chest showed multifocal pneumonia. 
With ongoing fevers, pulmonary was consulted and a BAL 
performed. No culprit lesion was identified and fluid samples 
sent for culture were negative. All other cultures, including 
blood, urine, and viral returned negative. Patient started on 
voriconazole and defervesed after 48 hours on fungal treatment 
on hospital day #6. Vancomycin, cefepime, and tamiflu were 
discontinued at that time; and patient was observed overnight on 
voriconazole and azitrhomycin. As patient was clinically well, 
had never had any signs of respiratory compromise or hypoxia, 
she was sent home on azithromycin with intent for close 
followup. Given findings on chest CT, pulmonary recommendations 
were to send for hypersensivity pneumonitis panel, which was 
pending at time fo discharge. Revlamid was restarted at time of 
discharge.

# Multiple Myeloma: Revlamid was ___ at time of admission. IgG 
subtype and T-Cell lymphocyte panel were obtained. Returned 
normal, although C4% percentage slightly below normal. There was 
no indication for IVIG, and home acyclovir prophylaxis was 
continued while patient in house. Revlamid restarted at time of 
discharge.

# Pain control. Pt declined oxycontin, as reports causes 
vomiting. Initially started on MS contin, but this also appeared 
to cause severe nausea. Pt's nausea controlled w/ zofran, and MS 
contin was discontinued. A fentanyl patch was initiated with 
good efficacy, few side effects, no drowsiness. ___ mg PO 
dilaudid given for breakthrough pain. Pt discharged with 
prescriptions for fentanyl patches and dilaudid, with an 
appointment to follow up with his outpatient oncologist. 

# Mantle cell lymphoma. Pt was initially declining chemotherapy 
as did not tolerate last cycle well. Is pursuing admission into 
a study, cannot have chemo within 3 weeks to be admitted and 
receive study drug. However, CT at admission showed progressive 
disease, extensive LA and enlarging mass in abdomen encasing 
vasculature. Progression likely pt's source of increased pain. 
Pt offered chemo as inpatient, but pt declined. Discharged home 
in stable condition, will decide next steps in consultation with 
his outpatient oncologists.

PRINCIPLE REASON FOR ADMISSION
___ year old woman with history of follicular lymphoma presents 
with progressive fatigue, poor appetite, and diarrhea following 
rituxin and bendamustine therapy.

ACTIVE PROBLEMS

# Fatigue: Likely chemotherapy related considering temporal 
relation compounded by dehydration due to poor po intake and 
diarrhea. Provided IVF's and patient noted to not be 
orthostatic. By discharge, patient was feeling much better with 
excellent appetite and ambulating well. TSH was noted to be 
normal.

# Diarrhea: Unclear etiology. Patietn was complaining of several 
large volume soft BM nightly for one week before admission. 
Temporally related to po contrast administration for outpatient 
CT scan, however lasted longer than expected. CDiff negative and 
patient had no signs or symptoms of significant infection 
including no fever or abdominal pain. Patient was treated 
symptomatically with lopearamide and lomotil with good effect.

# Anxiety: Patient noted to be very anxious during hospital 
stay. Required 0.25 mg lorazepam night of admission for mild 
anxiety attack with good relief.

CHRONIC PROBLEMS

# DM: Held metformin and glyburide while inpatient. Provided 
HISS with good control of blood sugar.

# HTN: Normotensive. Held home BP medications in light of 
diarrhea and likely dehydration. 

# HLD: Continued home statin.

# Hx of breast cancer. Not active. Held arimidex while 
inpatient.
.
# Follicular lymphoma: Patient to continue planned follow up 
with outpatient oncologist.

OUTSTANDING STUDIES
-None

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
-Continue planned follow up for follicular lymphoma and breast 
cancer

Brief Hospital Course:
Briefly, the patient is a ___ yo female with a history of active 
follicular lymphoma, receiving chemotherapy, who has had 
persistent diarrhea for the past 3 weeks, with 1 recent 
admission approximately 1 week prior for similar symptoms with 
no improvement.  
.
Diarrhea:  The patient was admitted for further work-up and 
evaluation of her diarrhea.  She had a CT scan done in the ER 
that showed only diverticulosis, as well as a question of some 
perirectal fat stranding concerning for possible perirectal 
fistula.  Given these findings, the patient was seen by the 
Colorectal Surgical Consult service in the ER, but they did not 
feel that there was any evidence of fistula or any need for 
surgical intervention, and recommended only that the patient be 
worked-up for her diarrhea.  After admission, the patient was 
seen by the GI service, and they felt that given the timing of 
her diarrhea, that it was most likely to be a side effect of her 
recent chemotherapeutic agent, bendamustine, which has a very 
high prevalence of diarrhea as a side effect.  However, 
infectious and inflammatory etiologies were also excluded with 
culture, as well as having the patient undergo a colonoscopy 
with biopsy.  All the culture data has thus far returned 
negative for infectious causes.  The colonoscopy did show 
non-specific inflammation in the sigmoid colon, as well as an 
ulcer in the sigmoid colon, which biopsy showed acute 
self-limited colitis, without any evidence of inclusion bodies 
or microorganisms, and CMV stain was negative as well.  
Following the colonoscopy, the patient was given anti-diarrheal 
agents and supplemental IVF, and her symptoms improved 
significantly.  On discharge, her diarrhea had resolved 
completely.  Of note, during the admission, an ___ Oncologist 
did see her daily, and was made aware of the likely diagnosis of 
chemotherapy-associated diarrhea.  As such, he will discuss this 
with the patient's outpatient oncologist for the need for 
possible adjustment to the patient chemotherapy regimen.  
.
Transitional Issues:
1.  Follow-up with her outpatient Oncologist to determine what 
chemotherapy adjustments need to be made, given her likely 
serious diarrhea from her prior chemotherapy agent.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo R-handed man with PMH significant for 
possible ___ disease, orthostatic hypotension who 
presented with worsening of his gait and speech, found to have 
an acute pontine infarct as well as incidental cavernous 
malformation in the left occipital horn. 

# Acute ischemic left pontine infarct: Patient presented with a 
new acute infarct on MRI which likely caused his symptoms on 
presentation including right pronator drift and right facial 
asymmetry. The etiology of the infarct was thought to be a small 
perforating vessel off the basilar artery which may have 
occluded due to patient's large fluctuations in blood pressure. 
He had very labile blood pressure while inpatient and is 
currently followed as an outpatient at the ___. He 
was evaluated by Dr. ___ recommended midodrine 5mg BID, 
increased free water (___) and salt intake, head of bed 
upright in reverse trendelenberg with the entire bed at an angle 
(not just head of bed elevated) in order to optimize his blood 
pressure regimen and curb the large fluctuations which may help 
diminish his risk of hypertensive stroke in the future. Patient 
should only be supine when sleeping. During the day, maximize 
time in the upright position. Encourage ambulation, if not 
ambulating should be in seated position with legs dangling. If 
not able to walk with physical therapy he should at least stand 
with physical therapy. He was also continued on aspirin and 
simvastatin. He was monitored on telemetry which showed sinus 
bradycardia. A TTE was negative for PFO ___. He will 
follow-up with stroke neurology as an outpatient. 

# Left occipital horn hemorrhage: On admission CT, there was a 
small area of hemorrhage likely secondary to carvernous 
malformation. This was an incidental finding and was not thought 
to be related to his neurologic complaints on admission.

# Parkinsonism, concern for Parkininson's Disease: Patient is 
followed by Dr. ___ in neurology clinic. The diagnosis of PD 
is not certain, and he has features of multiple system atrophy. 
He was continued on home pramipexole and will follow-up with Dr. 
___ as an outpatient.  

# Othostatic hypotension: Patient has a history of very labile 
blood pressures followed by Dr. ___ at the autonomic center. 
Consulted autonomics inpatient (Dr. ___ who recommended 
increasing PO water (at least ___ L per day), increasing salt 
intake, and starting midodrine BID. The last dose of midodrine 
should NOT be given later than 4 ___ to decrease the risk of 
supine hypertension. While the patient feels that midodrine led 
to his stroke, a careful analysis by autonomics revealed that 
the benefits outweighed the risks since midodrine will decrease 
the BP drop while standing. We stopped fludricortisone since 
this medication takes a long time to take effect and may lead to 
supine hypertension after discharge. He will follow-up with him 
as an outpatient for further management.

- During the ___ rehab stay, the following guidelines can 
help with managing autonomic dysfunction:

<< Supine hypertension >> 
-The patient should always be in the head up position (reverse 
Trendellenberg)) when supine (the entire bed is at an angle 
should not merely be sitting upright).  
-       If the patient experiences supine hypertension the head 
of the bed should be brought up or he should be sat up in a 
chair with his legs down - would not recommend treatment with 
antihypertensives if repositioning is enough to resolve his 
hypertension

<< Orthostatic hypotension >>
-Use midodrine (5 mg) on a sliding scale to maintain SBP above 
100 mmHg.  
-Ensure that midodrine dosing is not TID (i.e. 8 am, 4pm and 
midnight).  
-Last dose of midodrine should be 6 hours or more before 
bedtime.
-Dosing should be 8am, noon or 4pm.
-Do not use if patient is supine
-Blood pressure typically rises throughout the day so last 
doses of midodrine can often be lower than morning doses.

<< Fluid intake >> should be at least 3 litres per day and salt
intake up to 6 gram/day if no contraindications

<<To prevent deconditioning >>
-Patient should only be supine when sleeping.  
-During day maximize time in the upright position.  
-Encourage ambulation (with support as necessary).  
-If not ambulating should be in seated position with legs 
dangling
-If unable to walk due to low blood pressures, physical therapy 
should comprise moving from a seated to standing position for as 
much time as tolerated

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M with presumed cirrhosis, DMII, EtOH abuse, COPD with 
long and complicated outside hospital MICU course transferred to 
___ MICU for thoracic surgery evaluation of llarge RUL lung 
abscess. He was not felt to be a surgical candidate. He 
continued to have persistent fevers and leukocytosis despite 
targeted antibiotics. The decision was made for comfort measures 
only and he expired.

ACTIVE ISSUES:

# Sepsis with pulmonary source
He presented with sepsis evidenced by fever on arrival to MICU 
along with worsening leukocytosis to 20k. He had been off 
pressors since ___ at the OSH. He has multiple sources, but 
most notable and likely being the RUL abscess and multifocal 
pneumonia. OSH cultures grew aspergillus and enterbacter from 
the abscess and serratia from sputum. He was treated with 
voriconazole for aspergillus, meropenm for enterobacter and 
serratia, and tobramycin for presumed VAP. Vancomycin was not 
initially continued, but he had a subsequent rising leukocytosis 
so this was added. Here, he grew pseudomonas and acitentobacter 
from sputum. ID was consulted for assistance with antibiotics; 
he had multiple organisms with different sensitivity profiles, 
so antibiotics were targeted while balancing minimizing 
toxicity. However, source control was unable to be achieved 
given poor surgical candidacy. A family meeting was held given 
his poor prognosis and they and the patient reiterated that he 
did not want to be dependent upon the ventilator/HD and he was 
transitioned to comfort measures only and subsequently expired.

# Hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory failure
He underwent trach placement and remains ventilator dependent 
upon admission from OSH. Etiology multifactorial but most 
notably due to pulmonary abscess and multifoacal PNA in setting 
of radiographic COPD. He remained in on the ventilator while in 
the ICU on PSV. He had MV of ___ reflective are large dead 
space ventilation. He received antibiotics as below and 
albuterol/ipratropium inhalers. He underwent HD as below for 
assistance with volume removal.

# Pulmonary abscess and VAP
Described further as above. CT chest showed invasion of the 
abscess into the chest wall musculature. Thoracic surgery was 
consulted for possible surgical management. However, he was felt 
to be too high risk of a surgical candidate and this was not 
pursued.

# Unstageable sacral decubitus ulcer
Upon transfer he was found to have a large unstagable sacral 
decubitus ulcer. Acute care surgery was consulted and performed 
bedside debridements. A flexiseal was placed for fecal 
management. 

# Acute renal failure
Upon transfer he had continued oliguric ARF and was 
HD-dependent. This was felt ot be pre-renal with likely 
intrinsic renal injury from septic shock leading to ATN. He 
received HD while hospitalized and all medications were dosed 
accordingly.

# Maroon stool
He had a single maroon stool on transfer. He was hemodynamically 
stable. Etiology not clear, but CT reports do comment on sigmoid 
diverticuli. ___ have also been from ischemi colitis. C. diff 
was negative. 

# Atrial fibrillation
He remained hemodynamically stable. Amiodarone and metoprolol 
had been held at ___ amidst his septic physiology. 
Developed RVR and was restarted on metoprolol. 

# Foley trauma
Had hematuria from Foley trauma. Foley remained in place 
throughout hospitalization.

CHRONIC ISSUES:

# HTN: Held home atenolol

# HLD: held home simvastatin.

# DM: HISS.

# EtOH abuse: Outside of withdrawal window, though had been on 
midazolam recently, had no evidence of withdrawal while here.

# COPD: Albuterol/ipratropium as above

# Cirrhosis: Presumably EtOH-induced but not certain. INR 1.5 
but platelets in 200s suggesting some preserved synthetic 
function.

futher investigation.

inhalation BID

sided rib fractures.   Upon admission, the patient was made NPO 
and given intravenous fluids.  Because of her injuries, she was 
evaluated by the Orthopedic service.  The decision was made to 
take to patient to the operating room where she underwent an

minimal blood loss. At the close of the case the patient left 
arm was placed in a splint.  The patient was extubated after the 
procedure and monitored in the recovery room.

controlled with intravenous analgesia and later transitioned to 
oral agents. The patient was instructed in the use of the 
incentive spirometer.  She resumed a regular diet and was 
voiding without difficulty.  Prior to discharge, the patient was 
evaluated by physical and occupational therapy and deemed safe 
for discharge home. A follow-up appointment was made with the 
Orthopedic service in 2 weeks.  The patient was instructed to 
follow-up with her primary care provider for further evaluation

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were transferred to ___ 
___ after a fall and were found to have left-sided rib 
fractures and a left wrist fracture. You underwent repair of 
your right wrist fracture on ___. You are recovering well 
and are now ready for discharge. Please continue non-weight 
bearing of your left arm and keep splint in place, clean, and 
dry. Please follow the instructions below to continue your 
recovery:

Rib Fractures:
* Your injury caused 2 rib fractures which can cause severe pain 
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of 
the pain. 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician. 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs. 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing. 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain. 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible. 
* Do NOT smoke 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves. 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

PAIN MANAGEMENT: 
 o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain after surgery. This 
pain is often described as "soreness".  
 o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 

 o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. 
 o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before 
your pain gets too severe. 
 o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine. 

If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon: 
 - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours 
 - pain that is getting worse over time 
 - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101 
 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain 

   
MEDICATIONS: 
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently. 
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care!

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Team

likely related to her metastatic HCC. Diagnostic paracentesis 
negative for SBP. Family meeting was held in conjunction with

and focus on comfort care measures only. Prognosis very poor and 
given the rapidity of her decline, life expectancy of weeks to

no evidence of acute process and it was felt that her symptoms 
are secondary to her end stage underlying malignancy. She 
responded well to low dose oral dilaudid (standing) for pain.

control. She exhibited poor appetite and the family was 
encouraged to focus on comfort eating - small bites, frequently 
throughout the day and de-emphasized focus on nutrition. No 
indication for percutaneous gastric or jejunal feeding tube 
given her ascites. Family deferred nasogastric ___ given her

her elevated bilirubin with repeat CT scan to assess for biliary 
obstruction and possible percutaneous drain placement were 
declined by the patient and her family.

Brief Hospital Course:
In summary, the patient is a ___ female who presented 
with 1 week of worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea.  
.  
# Abdominal Pain/Diarrhea: After an extensive imaging and lab 
work-up the patient's abdominal pain etiology was still unclear. 
Work-up data with transvaginal ultrasound, abdominal & pelvic 
CT, vaginal swabs, and blood labs all essentially ruled out 
endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts w/torsion, ectopic 
pregnancy, GC/Chlamydia, appendicitis, kidney stones, colon 
pathology. Despite her benign gynecologic lab/imaging workup she 
had some mild tenderness on pelvic exam at her cervix. Thus, she 
was treated empirically for PID with Doxycycline and Cefotexan 
and advised that if this pain did not resolve or if she noticed 
any unusual odor, discharge or bleeding that she needed to 
follow-up with her primary care physician or see ___ gynecologist 
as soon as possible. 
.
Ultimately, based on the temporality and description of watery 
diarrhea it was felt that Ms. ___ have been 
experiencing a form of viral gastroenteritis, though the 
prominent abdominal pain was fairly atypical. Moreover, viral 
gastroenteritis is frequently associated with brief elevations 
in lipase which was noted with Ms. ___ labs with a 
lipase of 99. Pancreatitis was unlikely as her symptoms appeared 
to quickly resolve and she was able to tolerate a regular diet 
well within hours of her admission. Abdominal CT also showed no 
radiological signs of pancreatitis. Initially, vasculitis was 
considered but felt to be less likely based on normal ESR and 
guaiac negative stool. A rarer cause such as porphyria was 
briefly entrtained but this is usually more chronic, relapsing 
abdominal pain, often with neurological symptoms which the 
patient lacked. Lastly, the team considered IBD as an etiology 
given the component of diarrhea, but this was also doubted as 
IBD usually presents less acutely with a more chronic course. 
.
Upon admission she was initially placed on clear liquids but 
soon advanced to a regular diet which she tolerated very well 
with no additional diarrhea or vomiting and very minimal nausea. 
She was given additional IVFs for basic rehydration. For 
abdominal pain control she was given low doses of IV Dilaudid 
and then switched to PRN oral oxycodone. Compazine was given for 
nausea relief and Ativan was also given for dual anxiety and 
anti-nausea effects. Stool cultures and labs were ordered but 
the patient's diarrhea seemed to have abated after admission. 
She stated that she was not usually able to go to the bathroom 
in hospitals and had "trouble" feeling comfortable enough to 
have a bowel movement. Unfortunately, as sample was not 
collected but given the patient's desire to be discharged and 
her rapid clinical improvement she was not kept in the hospital 
simply to collect these studies. She was told, however, that if 
her diarrhea returned that she should return to the ED or call 
her primary care provider as stool studies would be an important 
part of the workup. At time of discharge home she was pain free 
and her nausea was nearly gone. She had no residual cramping or 
emesis either and she appeared much more alert and hydrated with 
moist mucous membranes and a less pallid complexion. She was 
asked to continue Tylenol as needed OTC for a week for any 
residual abdominal pain but not to exceed 3g/day.      
.
# Anxiety - During her hospital course she was given Ativan ___ 
mg PO every 4 hours as needed for anxiety. She denied any 
suicidal or homicidal thoughts but seemed to have a sad, flat 
affect. She reported no hallucinations or changes in her eating 
or sleeping habits. She described her mood as "steady" but 
explained she still got sad at times. She explained that she 
felt she did not need her Klonopin anymore so she had gradually 
tapered herself off of it over a period of ___ weeks. She took 
two tablets 3 days prior to admission. In the past she had taken 
up to 300mg daily of Effexor XR but she reported that she 
stopped taking this several months ago. She was started on 20mg 
Celexa for both anxiety and depression. Compliance was addressed 
and encouraged and she was advised to discuss possible dose 
adjustments at her upcoming primary care appointment and/or with 
her psychiatrist Dr. ___. She was also warned that abrupt 
discontinuation of this medication may be harmful. For 
additional anxiety control she was asked to restart her prior 
regimen of ___ Klonopin tablets as needed up to three times 
daily. The patient's psychiatrist was emailed regarding her 
condition and the patient was asked to call Dr. ___ to schedule 
an appointment as soon as possible.     
.  
# Fluids, electrolytes and nutrition: Daily electrolytes were 
monitored and repleted as needed and she was placed on a clear 
liquid diet and then soon advanced to a regular diet which she 
tolerated very well. Diarrhea and nausea resolved by time of 
discharge.  
.
#Prophylaxis: Ms. ___ was given subcutaneous Heparin for 
DVT prophylaxis and no bowel regimen was given in the setting of 
her recent diarrhea. 
.
The patient was maintained as a full code status for the 
entirety of her hospital stay and communication occurred 
directly with the patient on a daily basis. 
 
.

Conclusions  
The patient received intravenous dobutamine beginning at 15

because the target heart rate was achieved. There were no 
diagnostic ECG changes with exercise (see exercise report for

responses to stress.

blood pressure of 134/70 mmHg. These demonstrated normal 
regional and global left ventricular systolic function. At 
mid-dose dobutamine [30 mcg/kg/min; heart rate 93 bpm, blood 
pressure 158/70 mmHg), there was appropriate augmentation of all 
left ventricular segments. At peak dobutamine stress [45 
mcg/kg/min and 0.25 mg atropine; heart rate 127 bpm, blood 
pressure 164/70 mmHg), there appears to be new regional 
dysfunction in the distal lateral wall (see clip 27 compared to 
baseline clip 19 and early recovery clip 31). This may be due to 
image quality/off axis imaging.

echocardiographic evidence of inducible ischemia to 
pharmacologic stress.

post-exercise acquisitions.

# Fever -  The patient initially presented with fevers to 104.0, 
dyspnea and cyanosis at home. He was treated for CHF 
exacerbation and pneumonia with initial improvement in his sxs 
despite unimpressive CXR. His urine and blood cultures returned

origin as that would require a duration of 3 weeks with no known 
source. The patient was afebrile during the hospitalization and 
antibiotics were discontinued on ___ without return of fever. 
Repeat chest x-ray showed no signs of pneumonia, pleural 
effusion or pulmonary edema. Urine culture showed no growth. 
Patient's presentation was most consistent with a viral lower 
respiratory infection triggering afib with RVR and a CHF 
exacerbation, which had been controlled prior to transfer. 
However, given the association with a new onset eruptive rash, 
immune or vascular etiologies were considered, and biopsies were 
taken by dermatology as below. 

# Rash - Patient was transferred from ___ because of concern 
that his skin rash was consistent with a vasculitis or 
autoimmune disorder. The rash consists of red papules ~0.5mm in 
diameter and looks to be consistent with cherry hemangiomas, 
which dermatology consult agredd with. However, the reason for a 
sudden eruption was unclear. Per dermatology, this could be seen 
with medications or multiple myeloma. Patient recently took a 
course of bactrim for UTI. Skin biopsies were taken, and 
pathology confirmed cherry hemangiomas. SPEP and UPEP were 
pending on discharge, and patient's PCP ___ with 
results.

# Left renal thickening - There was concern by ___ Urology, 
Dr. ___ renal stone given fever and abnormal findings 
on CT abd/pelvis, which was done with contrast. He requested a 
repeat CT w/o to look for stones and urine cytology. CT w/o 
contrast confirmed lack of stone. He has ___ appointment 
with urology to ___ the left renal thickening.

# CAD - Patient had 6 vessel CABG many years ago (unclear how 
many). He did not have any chest pain during the admission. The 
patient had nonspecific ST changes as well as TWI on EKG which 
were thought to be due to memory T waves, however given his 
history he underwent a pharmacologic stress echo.  This 
demonstrated no diagnostic ECG changes but with possible 2D 
echocardiographic evidence of inducible ischemia to 
pharmacologic stress. On further discussion with the reading 
cardiologist, given his presentation this was thought to be 
unlikely due to CAD/ischemia, may be due to image quality/off 
axis imaging.  His medical regimen was therefore optimized, afib 
treated as below and cardiology f/u scheduled.  Home aspirin, 
metoprolol, isosorbide mononitrate were continued during 
admission. 

# Afib: New onset since arrival at ___.  EKG done on the 
floor was consistent with coarse a.fib, and was reviewed with 
cardiology given new TWI, thought to be due to memory t waves in 
the setting of recent pacing. The patient now has a CHADS2 score 
of 3 based on CHF, HTN and A.fib as well as possible new onset 
diabetes (see issue of HBA1c below). He was started on warfarin 
prior to discharge and will ___ with his PCP for 
management.

Patient had an elevated HBA1c of 6.2 which puts him in the range 
of prediabetes.

The patient had an elevated TSH of 6.7 with a slightly decreased 
T4 of 0.7. This is consistent with primary hypothyroidism due to 
a dysfunction of the thyroid gland. Sick euthyroid syndrome 
presents with central hypothyroidism with decrease in both TSH 
and T4 so his lab abnormalities are likely due to another cause. 
Notably, furosemide is known to reduce T4 binding to TBG as 
found in (J Clin Endocrinol Metab. ___. He 
is not currently showing any signs of hypothyroidism so this was 
noted in transitional issues to be followed as an outpatient.

___ at ___. Elevation was attributed to rigors, which is 
consistent with the normalization on repeat level. Simvastatin 
80mg was changed to atorvastatin 40mg as simvastatin doses above 
20mg have been shown to have increased risk of myalgias when 
taken with amlodipine.

moderate pulmonary hypertension. BNP was elevated to 3000 at

Discharge Instructions:
Elective Aneurysm Clipping

Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:

-Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
movement

-Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision

-Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy

-Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

-Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications

Activity:

-Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.

-Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days 
after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more 
detail at the time of your suture removal.  

Incision Care:

-Keep your wound clean and dry.

-Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 

-When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
dry.

-Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
incision line.

-You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical

-Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away 
after about a month

-You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be 
prevented by:

oDrinking plenty of fluids
oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
oExercising
oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as 
needed, stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements 
or diarrhea

-Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time

-Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can 
take weeks or months to fully resolve

-Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area

-Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
with increased activity

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional

-You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include

oFeeling down or sad
oIrritability, frustration, and confusion
oDistractibility
oLower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
oInsomnia
oLoneliness

-If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
Psychiatrist

-You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation

oMore information can be found at ___

 
Followup Instructions:
___

draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office.

NSAIDs.

minimizing oxycodone, and starting Seroquel.

waxing/waning confusion consistent with delirium on dementia.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female who was admitted to the hospital with right 
lower quadrant pain.  Upon admission, the patient was made NPO, 
given intravenous fluids, and underwent imaging. A cat scan of 
the abdomen and pelvis was done which showed an acute ruptured 
appendix with surrounding phlegmonous change.  No drainable 
abscess was identified.  Because of these findings, the patient 
was started on a course of ciprofloxacin and flagyl.  Her vital 
signs and white blood cell count were monitored and the patient 
underwent serial abdominal exams.  

On HD # 2, the patient was started on a clear liquid diet after 
she reported a decrease in her abdominal pain. After return of 
bowel function, she resumed a regular diet. The patient's vital 
signs remained stable and she was afebrile.  Her white blood 
cell count normalized.  The patient was discharged home on a 10 
day course of antibiotics.  A follow-up examination in the Acute 
care clinic was scheduled with Dr. ___ on ___.  Signs and 
symptoms of infection were reviewed with the patient at the time 
of discharge. 

Of note: the patient was informed of the cat scan finding of a 
incompletely characterized 3.2 x 2.6 cm left adrenal mass and 
the need for additional imaging.   A copy of the report was 
given to the patient.  The patient reported that she had been 
aware of this finding in the past and has been followed.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ was a ___ male with past medical history of 
significant EtOH use disorder, opiate use disorder on methadone, 
depression, who presented as a transfer from ___ 
___ in 3 pressor shock with evidence of acute liver failure 
and oliguric renal failure, positive ethanol, with suspicion of 
severe alcoholic hepatitis. 

He was intubated due to unresponsiveness, placed on CRRT for 
worsening renal failure and acidemia, and on 4 pressors and 
stress dose steroids, with broad spectrum antibiotics provided 
without clear source of infection. NAC was given for acute liver 
failure, and workup was negative for alternative cause of 
hepatic failure beyond ethanol alcohol. He had coaguloaphty and 
both upper GI bleeding (scoped by GI, no varices, 2 shallow 
___ tears, no intervention needed) and nasopharyngeal 
bleeding (packed by ENT). His lactate continued to rise despite 
adequate pressures, raising concern for ischemic bowel, but he 
was unstable for CT scan. Infectious workup failed to reveal any 
source of infection or culture any pathogen.

On day of death, despite 4 pressors and sufficient systolic 
pressures, his diastolics were mainly in the ___, with worsening 
acidemia worsened despite CRRT and Bicarb drip, and rising 
lactate. After 3 days of aggressive supportive care, family 
decided to transition him to comfort measures only. He was 
palliatively extubated and pressors stopped at 1640, and he died 
at 1705.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female who presented to ___ on ___ 
with epigastric pain.  The patient continued to have frequent 
episodes of non-bloody emesis, IV Zofran did not relieve the 
nausea. During the hospital course, she underwent an EGD.  GI 
was unable to pass the scope past the stomach which was 
concerning for incarceration causing the GOO. Her hospital 
course was complicated by fever and leukocytosis to 12.4 with 
neutrophilic predominance. There was a concern for suspected 
aspiration pneumonia and the patient was started on a course of 
zosyn. A non-contrast CT of the abdomen was done which  showed 
free air in the hiatal hernia sac concerning for gastric 
incarceration within the hernia and perforation.  The patient 
was transferred here for management.

Upon admission, the patient was made NPO and given intravenous 
fluids. She was started on vancommycin, in addition to the zosyn 
for aspiration pneumonia.  She was taken to the operating room 
where she underwent repair of an incarcerated, para-esophageal 
hernia, resection of the greater gastric curve, incomplete wrap 
of the hiatus, and placemment of a GJ feeding tube. The 
operative course was stable with a 100cc blood loss.  The 
patient was extubated after the procedure and monitored in the 
recovery room.

Her post-operative course was stable.  Her incisional pain was 
controlled with PCA.  The patient's foley catheter was removed 
on POD # 1 and the patient voided without difficulty.  The G 
tube was placed to gravity drainage and trophic tube feedings 
were started via the J tube.  The patient reported increased 
fullness after the initiation of tube feedings and the tube 
feedings were held. Her antibiotics were discontinued on POD #1. 
On ___, the patient underwent an UGI to evaluate the motility 
status of the esophagus and stomach.  It showed no esophageal 
stricture and no recurrent hernia and the patient resumed a 
regular diet on POD #3. Her PCA was discontinued and she was 
started on oral analgesia.  

The patient was discharged home on POD #7 in stable condition.  
Her GJ was clamped and she was tolerating a regular diet.  She 
had return of bowel function.  Her vital signs were stable and 
she was afebrile.  She was ambulatory and voiding without 
difficulty.  An appointment for follow-up was made with Dr. 
___ in the acute care clinic.

vitamin D, ferrous gluconate 325", HCTZ 25, losartan 200, K-Dur 
20meq", omeprazole 20", levobunolol gtt both eyes, Ca carbonate 
500, MVI, spiriva 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 
4. Levobunolol 0.5% 1 DROP BOTH EYES DAILY 
5. Losartan Potassium 200 mg PO DAILY 
6. Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID 
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  2.5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
8. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Incarcerated strangulated paraesophageal hernia.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with upper abdominal pain.  
You underwent a cat scan of the abdomen which was concerning for 
a gastric perforation. You were taken to the operating room 
where you were found to have a strangulated para-esophageal 
hernia. You underwent repair of the hernia and placement of a 
G-J tube for nutrition.  You are slowly recovering from your 
surgery.  You have resumed a regular diet.  Your vital signs 
have been stable.  You are preparing for discharge home  with 
the following instructions:  

Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 6 weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.)
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first.
You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you 
otherwise.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
 
You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want to 
nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You 
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Your incision may be slightly red aroudn the stitches or 
staples. This is normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin 
paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall 
off before that that's okay).
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision. This will 
go away.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing r clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
Ove the next ___ months, your incision will fade and become 
less prominent.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as 
Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk 
of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon.
After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get diarrhea, 
don't take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of fluitds and 
see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is severe and 
you feel ill, please call your surgeon.
 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription from your surgeon for pain 
medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine 
as directied. Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do 
not take more medicine at one time than prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
IF you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the folloiwng, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
In some cases you will have a prescription for antibiotics or 
other medication.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness 
or abdominal pain

medications.

heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

bowel movement.

urine, or experience a discharge.

Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

you.

advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

IMPRESSION:
1. There is an infiltrative process in segment IVB of the liver 
with a 23 mm posterior mass as well as an additional 10 mm 
nodule anteriorly with delayed enhancement concerning for a 
cholangiocarcinoma. The mass extends into the porta hepatis 
where it obstructs the biliary tree. There is metastatic 
adenopathy in the upper abdomen, diffuse moderate intrahepatic 
biliary dilatation with a normal caliber pancreatic duct and 
common bile duct, and a sludge-filled gallbladder with 
submucosal edema, all secondary to the liver mass. Recommend GI 
consultation for consideration of ERCP versus transhepatic 
cholangiogram. Image guided liver biopsy should also be strongly 
considered.

ureter with wall thickening which could be neoplastic, either 
primary or secondary, or postinflammatory. Recommend urology 
consultation.

ERCP ___:
Impression:
The scout film was normal.
The major papilla appeared normal.
The bile duct was successfully cannulated using a Rx 
sphincterotome preloaded with a 0.035in guidewire. Contrast was 
injected and there was brisk flow through the ducts. Contrast 
extended to the entire biliary tree.
Contrast injection showed a single 2.5 cm long tight stricture 
at the level of the higher CHD up to the hilum, compatible with 
a Bismuth type II cholangiocarcinoma. There was significant 
post-obstructive dilation of the right and left main hepatic 
ducts. The CBD presented a normal caliber.
A biliary sphincterotomy was successfully performed with the 
sphincterotome. There was no post-sphincterotomy bleeding.
A cytology brush was then inserted to obtain specimen from the 
stricture which was sent for cytology.
Subsequently, a ___ x 5cm biliary double pigtail plastic stent 
(Cotton ___ was successfully placed across the stricture 
using a preloaded OASIS stent introducer kit.
Excellent bile and contrast drainage was seen endoscopically and 
fluoroscopically. I supervised the acquisition and 
interpretation of the fluoroscopic images. The quality of the 
fluoroscopic images was good.

hydroureter with
ureteral kinking and abrupt transition in its midportion at the 
level of L3.
Although findings are in a typical location of a UPJ 
obstruction, there is
associated urothelial hyperenhancement and although no discrete 
lesion is seen
a ureteroscopy is recommended to exclude an underlying lesion.
2. Delayed contrast excretion from the left kidney.
3. Intrahepatic biliary obstruction to the level of the common 
hepatic duct
with a partially imaged ill-defined mass at the level of the 
porta hepatis,
better evaluated on dedicated MRCP from Atrius.
4. Suspicious porta hepatic/celiac chain lymphadenopathy.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is ___ yo F with ESRD on HD who presented with fever at 
her hemodialysis center with positive blood cultures for MSSA. 
She was admitted to the hospital for a line holiday and also 
treatment of her bacteremia. 
.  
# Bacteremia: The patient had positive blood cultures at 
hemodialysis; sensitivities were sent to us revealing MSSA. 
Blood cultures were again positive here, growing MSSA, on 
___. Catheter tip was also positive for staph at that time. 
The line was pulled and a new line was not placed. The patient 
was initially treated with Vancomycin during hemodialysis; this 
was switched to Cefazolin during hemodialysis once sensitivities 
returned. The patient will remain on a six week course of 
Cefazolin, to treat bacteremia and to cover endocarditis (see 
below.) Importantly, she will need weekly surveillance labs to 
be drawn at hemodialysis and faxed to infectious disease while 
she is on Cefazolin.
.
Of note, the patient remained hemodynamically stable and 
non-septic throughout her stay. She was afebrile with the 
exception of one low grade fever to 100.6 the night before 
discharge. She did have a soft murmur on exam but never 
developed stigmata of endocarditis on exam.
.
The ID team was consulted and followed. They recommended 
surveillance imaging. A CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast was 
negative for abscess or other evidence of infection. A TTE was 
performed (see anatomical details below) and did not show 
vegetations. In consultation with ID and Renal we decided not to 
pursue a TEE in the patient given the fact that she continued to 
have negative blood cultures after the line was drawn and that 
the TEE itself has risks of aspiration in an ___ year old woman. 
Both the ID and renal teams were in agreement with this plan. 
.
Finally, an upper extremity vascular U/S did show thrombus in 
the inferior aspect of the right IJ, where her hemodialysis line 
had previously been placed. This was discussed with the ___ 
team, who felt strongly that the patient should not be 
anti-coagulated given the low risk of PE with RIJ thrombus and 
also the fact that they suspect that they clot has been there 
for a long time surrounding her HD line. In addition, they felt 
that the risks of anti-coagulation outweighed the benefits; 
clearly there is a general risk of bleeding with 
anti-coagulation, but specifically there is a risk of 
infiltration of the AV fistula which is already tenuous. After 
extensive discussion with Renal, and with the family, the 
decision was made not to anti-coagulate. However, the patient 
was set up with Heme-Onc followup for followup of this clot. The 
patient should get imaging in a few months to look for 
resolution- this should be followed by Heme-Onc and the 
patient's PCP.  
.  
# ESRD on HD: The patient was continued on HD here. After her HD 
line was pulled, her AV fistula was used. Dr. ___ the 
renal team were very involved in her course here and will be 
following her as an outpatient. She will be dosed with Cefazolin 
at HD and have weekly labs drawn there. She will continued on a 
___ schedule. Of note, her Phos was low 
throughout her hospitalization. Sevalamer was held on discharge 
and should be restarted by her Renal team when appropriate.
. 
# Structural Heart Disease: The patient has no report of 
structural heart disease in our records. However, Echo here 
revealed severe MR, hyperdynamic EF, pulmonary hypertension and 
PCWP 18 on ECHO with no previous echo for comparison. Her lungs 
clear on exam and so she did not appear to be in heart failure. 
However, a followup appointment was made with cardiology for 
maximization of her medication regimen in the setting of these 
new findings and to establish followup. 
.
# Leukopenia/Thrombocytopenia: The patient presented with 
leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. In looking back in labs in our 
system from ___ and recent labs faxed to us from ___ clinic, it 
appears that these values have been trending down over time. 
Etiology is unknown to us; her PCP was emailed about this, but 
we have not heard back as to whether she has already had a 
workup for these issues. Of note, these values improved over her 
course and likely were partially related to infection. This 
should be followed up by her PCP. 
.
# Anemia: Patient presented with anemia, that was stable 
thoughout her admission. It is unclear as to whether she is or 
should be on epogen at baseline. B12, folate normal. Renal and 
her PCP should follow up this issue. 
. 
# HTN: Continued on her home meds.

your physicians at hemodialysis found that you had bacteria in 
your blood. We repeated cultures of your blood here which 
confirmed this. We treated you with Vancomycin and removed the 
hemodialysis catheter, which we think caused this infection.
.
For hemodialysis in the coming weeks, the renal doctors ___ use 
your AV fistula instead of placing a new line. They will treat 
you with Cefazolin, another antibiotic, during hemodialysis to 
treat your infection. You will require 6 weeks of treatment with 
this antibiotics.
.
While you were here, we did a few imaging studies to look for 
infections in other areas of your body. The CT scan of your 
abdomen showed no infection. We did an echo of your heart that 
also showed no infection. This echo however did show some 
dysfunction which will need to be followed up by a cardiologist. 
Finally, the neck U/S did show a clot. There is a low risk of 
complications of clot, such as the clot moving to your lungs, 
but in extensive discussion with Dr. ___ think that the 
risks outweigh the benefits of treatment with blood thinners. 
However, we would like you to follow in ___ 
clinic (see appointments below.)
.
Please make the following changes to your medications:
- Cefazolin: This is an antibiotic that will be given to you 
during hemodialysis.
- STOP your sevalamer TEMPORARILY, given that your Phos levels 
have been very low. Your renal team can decide when to restart 
this.
.
Please take all of your other medications like you were prior to 
admission.
Please go to all of the followup appointments below.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ is an ___ ___ speaking female with ___ ESRD on 
dialysis, CHF LVEF 55% and myelodysplastic syndrome presents 
from dialysis with fever to 103 and cough. She was neutropenic 
with an ANC of less than 650 and her platelets were 24. She was 
admitted and placed on vancomycin and cefepime to cover HCAP.  
While on the floor the patient had an unwitnessed mechanical 
fall in which she struck her right shoulder. She was seen and 
through a translater she denied head strike, LOC, N/V, change in 
vision or headache. She reported that she ___ her right 
shoulder. Her exam was not notable other than pain in the right 
shoulder. She had right shoulder films that were not notable for 
fracture or dislocation. She was able to follow commands.

Throughout the day the patient became difficult increasingly 
difficult to understand. Per the translator the patient had a 
difficult to understand ___ accent. The family was 
contacted and per the family the patient was able to answer 
questions but was more confused than she had been the previous 
day. It was thought that this was due to her presumed PNA. 
However given this AMS a head CT was ordered. The patient became 
increasingly altered and when she was to be transported to have 
her head CT, she triggered for hypoxia. She was given 
nebulizers, had a CXR that showed increasing PNA and pulmonary 
edema. Azithromycin was added to her antibiotics and renal was 
contacted and she had emergent dialysis. In addition she was 
transfused 2 units of PRBCs while receiving dialysis. The 
patient stabilized from a respiratory standpoint and was taken 
for a head CT that showed a large parenchymal hemorrhage in the 
left parietal and temporal lobes with extension into the 
subarachnoid and subdural spaces and intraventricular extent, 
and with severe associated mass effect. The patient was given 
mannitol and transfused platelets and transfered to the SICU 
with neurosurgery.

There medical management was continued with platelet transfusion

Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history notable 
for fibromyalgia and abnormal muscle biopsy who presents with 3 
days of severe abrupt-onset headaches, found to have convexal 
SAH on CT imaging at OSH. Follow-up MRI redemonstrated cSAH 
without evidence of underlying mass, vascular malformation, or 
microhemorrhages. Accordingly, in the absence of anatomic or 
traumatic etiologies for the cSAH, suspicion was raised for 
reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS). Although 
Ms. ___ did not report recent changes to her SSRI, 
SSRI medications have been associated with worsening RCVS, so 
her escitalopram was discontinued. A review of her dietary 
supplements also did not reveal a studied cause of worsening 
RCVS, though a recommendation was made to discontinue these 
medications if a clear medical indication was not present given 
the potential risk for interaction with her RCVS. Follow-up 
arranged with vascular neurology for likely re-imaging to assess 
for vasospasm, and encouraged follow-up with rheumatology to 
discuss alternate treatment options for fibromyalgia and with 
outpatient neurologist for review of muscle biopsy (which, per 
___ records, revealed abnormal mitochondrial morphology but did 
not include a pathologic diagnosis of mitochondrial disease).

She should continue with Verapamil as a treatment for her RVCS 
until she sees Dr. ___ in clinic in a few months.

vasoconstriction.

fibromyalgia due to concern for vasoconstriction in setting of 
RCVS.

on ___.

Dilaudid.  She was also on IV Toradol and scheduled Tylenol.  
She was given IV fluids.  She was continued on folic acid and

recommended transfusion if Hct <18 (Hgb<6) or 2 point drop from 
baseline.  Transufsed 1 unit on ___. She was weaned 
to IV pain meds and ultimately transitioned to home regimen on

difficile test and stool ova/parasite exam. Likely side effect 
of augmentin, with course completed while inpatient for

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital with a sickle cell crisis.  We believe 
your sickle cell crisis was triggered by a sinus infection.  You 
were treated with pain medications and fluids for your sickle 
cell crisis with improvement in your pain. You are now ready for 
discharge and will be discharged on your home pain medications.  
 

An MRI of your brain showed an abnormality called Chiari 1 
malformation. The base of your brain is shaped different from 
others.  This is something you were born with. It is not causing 
you any harm but will need to be monitored over time by a 
neurologist for repeat head imaging.

While you were here you were noted to have elevated eosinophils, 
a type of white blood cell. This can sometimes happen due to 
medications or an allergic reaction. Your eosinophils were 
improving at discharge. You should follow-up with your 
hematologist for further work-up of this. 

Please follow-up with your primary care doctor, ___, 
and a Neurologist after discharge.

It was a pleasure taking care of you,
Your ___ Care Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service on ___ 
after a fall sustaining left sided rib fractures. You were found 
to have a moderate amount of fluid in the lung space that was 
caused by the injury to your ribs.  A chest tube was placed to 
help drain this fluid from your lung space and was then later 
removed.  You were given pain medication, supplemental oxygen, 
and encouraged to take deep breaths, walk, and cough to help 
your body re-absorb the fluid. You are now doing better, oxygen 
levels are adequate, and your pain is better controlled with 
pain pills. You were evaluated by the physical therapist who 
recommends discharge to home with continued physical therapy at 
home. You will also have visiting nursing services come to your 
home. 

Please have a follow up chest xray done prior to your clinic 
visit. 

Please note the following discharge instructions:

* Your injury caused left sided rib fractures which can cause 
severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths 
because of the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

     You were hospitalized due to symptoms of unresponsiveness 
resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a 
blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is 
blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that 
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage 
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result 
in a variety of symptoms.  

     Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you 
for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having 
stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify 
those risk factors. Your risk factors are:  
   
     - High blood pressure
     - High cholesterol
     - Poor heart function

 We are changing your medications as follows:  
 
     - Added
           - Aspirin 81mg daily
           - Atorvastatin 20mg daily
           - Phosphorus 250mg twice a day
      -Stopped Ensure

 Please take your other medications as prescribed.  

 Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.
  
     If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  

 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body
  
 Sincerely,  

 Your ___ Neurology Team

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital for a blood 
clot in your right arm. You had medications given in the arm to 
help break up the clot. To do the procedure, a small puncture 
was made in one of your arteries.  The puncture site heals on 
its own: there are no stitches to remove.   You tolerated the 
procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

Peripheral Angiography
Puncture Site Care
For one week:
Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
tub.
Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
the puncture site. 
Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
puncture site. 

You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
normal and will go away one-two weeks. 
Activity 
For the first 48 hours: 
Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
For the first week:
Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
pounds
Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
or moving your bowels.
After one week:
You may go back to all your regular activities, including 
sexual activity.  We suggest you begin your exercise program at 
half of your usual routine for the first few days.   You may 
then gradually work back to your full routine.

Medications:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

For  Problems or Questions:
Call ___ in an emergency such as:
Sudden, brisk bleeding or swelling at the puncture site that 
does not stop after applying pressure for ___ minutes
Bleeding that is associated with nausea, weakness, or 
fainting.
Call the vascular surgery office (___) right away if 
you have any of the following. (Please note that someone is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week)
Swelling, bleeding, drainage, or discomfort at the puncture 
site that is new or increasing since discharge from the hospital
Any change in sensation or temperature in your legs
Fever of 101 or greater
Any questions or concerns about recovery from your angiogram

Providers must include:

ANTICOAGULATION: Apixaban 5 mg twice daily

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ on ___ for planned right first 
rib resection for thoracic outlet syndrome associated with 
previous DVT and pulmonary embolism. At the initiation of this 
procedure the patient had an apparent allergic reaction which 
was primarily cutaneous in nature (diffuse redness of skin) but 
also associated with some hypotension which was treated 
successfully with steroids and epinephrine by the 
anesthesiologist. As multiple drugs were given and products used 
in close succession, it is difficult to say exactly to which 
item she was allergic. We have highest suspicion for vancomycin 
but rocuronium was also administered around the same time. She 
had also recently been prepped for surgery with a ChloraPrep 
scrub. For full details of this event and the remainder of the 
surgery, which proceeded as planned, please see the operative 
note and the anesthesia record. The patient was brought to the 
PACU and then surgical floor for further recovery in good 
condition. A chest tube was left at the end of the case and 
placed to suction. It was noted to have an air leak upon 
immediate conclusion of surgery, however this resolved by 
post-operative check approximately 1 hour later. Two chest 
x-rays were reassuring for minimal to no pneumothorax and she 
maintained saturations well. She consistently had a palpable 
right radial pulse from the end of the case until discharge and 
experienced no swelling of the right arm.

On the surgical floor, the patient remained hemodynamically 
stable. She was started on a 5 day course of Benadryl and 
methylprednisolone for her intraoperative allergic reaction and 
experienced no recurrence of allergic symptoms while inpatient. 
Her chest tube was transitioned to water seal on the morning of 
POD1. Chest x ray was reassuring and she was taken off the 
Pleurevac and placed on JP bulb suction with another reassuring 
chest X ray taken afterward. JP outputs were monitored and found 
to be sanguinous-tinged serous in color and thin in quality. As 
output was still in the 300-400 cc per day range as of the 
morning of POD2, it was determined that she would be best served 
by completing JP teaching and chest tube teaching, arranging for 
a visiting nurse, and arranging close clinic follow-up for tube 
removal in the next few days. All of these were arranged. A 
morning CXR on ___ was again reassuring. She continued to 
ambulate, tolerate a diet, and remained hemodynamically stable 
with no further allergic symptoms. On the afternoon of ___ she 
did note some minor swelling of the left foot. She has a known 
history of lymphedema on this side and the swelling was 
monitored for about two hours with no worsening on exam and some 
subjective improvement reported by the patient. She continued to 
ambulate and was instructed to call our clinic or answering 
service if this swelling worsened or began to extend beyond her 
foot. She was cleared for home with services and was instructed 
to restart home apixaban on discharge as well as to finish her 
steroid and benadryl course. All instructions, particularly in 
regard to medications and chest drain care (including 
contingencies if the bulb were to dislodge), were reviewed with 
patient and family prior to discharge, and all questions were 
answered to their satisfaction.
