Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital for surgery 
to remove your right first rib.  This surgery was done to 
restore proper blood flow to and from your arm.  To perform this 
procedure, an incision was made in your chest.

You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to be 
discharged from the hospital.   Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery.

First Rib Resection

Patient Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT:
Bruising, tenderness, mild swelling, numbness and/or a firm 
ridge at the incision site is normal.  This will improve 
gradually in the next 2 weeks. 

It is normal to feel tired for a few weeks after your surgery. 

MEDICATION INSTRUCTIONS:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for neck 
pain.  You may also take your prescription pain medication as 
needed when the pain requires more than Tylenol.  You should 
require less pain medication each day.  Do not take more than a 
daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  Tylenol is used as an 
ingredient in some other over-the-counter and prescription 
medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you are taking in a 
day.

You should continue to take Benadryl and methylprednisolone to 
complete a ___fter your allergic reaction in the 
operating room. Do not take Benadryl within an hour of taking 
any narcotic painkiller as this may cause too much sedation and 
difficulty breathing. We cannot say for sure what caused your 
allergic reaction. We think the antibiotic vancomycin is the 
most likely, but you also received rocuronium (a paralytic 
anesthetic drug used during surgeries) and ChloraPrep (a 
surgical scrub) at around the same time.

Narcotic pain medication can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative.  

CARE OF YOUR INCISION: 
You may shower.  Avoid direct shower spray to the incision 
(which is covered with skin glue) or chest tube site.  Let soapy 
water run over the incisions, then rinse and gently pat the area 
dry.  Do not scrub.  Keep a gauze or drain sponge around the 
site where your chest tube inserts to help make the tube as 
comfortable as possible. 

ACTIVITY: 
Do not drive for at least one week after your procedure.  Do not 
ever drive after taking narcotic pain medication. 

You should not push, pull, lift or carry anything heavier than 5 
pounds for the next 2 weeks. 

After 2 weeks, you may return to your regular activities 
including exercise, sexual activitiy and work. 

DIET: 
It is normal to have a decreased appetite.  Your appetite will 
return over time.  Follow a well-balanced, healthy diet.

CHEST TUBE/DRAIN:
We have placed a tube into your chest to ensure your lung 
remains expanded and help drain any fluid to the outside of your 
body rather than into your lung. Your lung is re-expanded on 
chest x-ray but you currently still require the tube to ensure 
good drainage of the drainage from your surgical site. Your 
visiting nurse ___ help you care for the device. Try to ensure 
that the drain does not twist or kink. When the bulb is emptied, 
it is VERY IMPORTANT that the tube that connects to your chest 
is clamped off. This can be accomplished by using ___ clamp 
or chest tube clamp placed over a gauze onto the tube (the gauze 
is to protect the tube from cracks when pressure is placed on 
it).  

* If your drain ever falls out or becomes disconnected from your 
bulb, the first thing you should do is reconnect the bulb and 
tape it securely. Then call our clinic or go to the ER. If the 
bulb is lost or you can't reconnect it, clamp the tube to 
prevent air from moving into your chest.*If you develop any 
chest pain or increased shortness of breath, please call 
immediately or go to the emergency room.

The gauze dressing around your chest tube should be changed at 
least every other day. 

Showering with a chest tube is okay. Do not submerge the tube or 
bulb device in water. No baths, swimming, or hot tubs. 

CALLING FOR HELP 
If you need help, please call us at ___.  Remember your 
doctor, or someone covering for your doctor is available 24 
hours a day, 7 days a week.  If you call during non-business 
hours, you will reach someone who can help you reach the 
vascular surgeon on call.  

To get help right away, call ___. 

Call the surgeon right away for:
·     severe shortness of breath
·     arm swelling, new or increasing arm tingling. If you 
experience significant loss of sensation in the arm, or if the 
arm turns blue or cold, go to the emergency room.
·     headache that is not controlled with pain medication or 
headache that is getting worse
·     fever of 101 degrees or more
·     bleeding from the incisions, drainage that is new or 
increased, or drainage that is yellow or green from either the 
incision or the chest tube
·     pain that is not relieved with medication, or pain that is 
getting worse instead of better

If you notice any of the following signs of stroke, call ___ to 
get help right away.
·     sudden numbness or weakness of the arm
·     severe shortness of breath or increased pain with 
breathing

___

causing severe symptoms given underlying structural disease due

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of horizontal and vertical 
double vision resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a 
condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to 
the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your 
body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, 
so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply 
can result in a variety of symptoms.
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
Prior Strokes
Prior TIA
Age
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Atherosclerosis of vessels that lead from heart to brain  

We are changing your medications as follows:

- We STOPPED rosuvastatin and STARTED atorvastatin 80 mg daily.
- We STARTED clopidogrel (brand name ___ 75 mg daily for 4 
weeks (Last Day ___ in addition to aspirin 81 mg which you 
should take ongoing. 
- We want you to continue taking aspirin 81 mg indefinitely
- Continue taking your other medications.
- Please follow-up with your primary care provider regarding 
diabetes management.

Please take your other medications as prescribed.
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body
Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

fluids keeping urine output at over >30cc/hour.  She provided 
with pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On 
POD1, the patient was transitioned from PCA to oral medications 
with the advancement to clears diet. She poorly tolerated the 
narcotics which caused dizziness, nausea and a general "unwell" 
feeling. She did not have emesis but did experience periorid 
nausea. This limited her cooperation with early mobilization and 
deep inspiration, incentive spirometry use. She is known to have

medications and anti-emetics and subsequently ambulated and 
advanced to clears with toast and crackers. She was not given 
Toradol because of her POD1 creatinine. At her request her 
narcotics were adjusted. Basic metabolic panel and complete 
blood count were checked daily. On POD2 her pain was moderately 
well controlled ranging from ___. Ms. ___ ambulated and 
continued to use the incentive spirometer. She was able to 
ambulate on room air without requirement of supplemental oxygen 
to keep her saturation greater than 92%. She did not feel well

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

supplements that may have blood-thinning effects (like Fish

even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  For pain 
control, try TYLENOL FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

stool (dark, tarry stools)

fluids to keep hydrated

otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___. 
REPLACE the Tylenol with this narcotic pain medication if 
additional pain control is needed.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up 

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool-softener, NOT a laxative

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old female s/p bioprosthetic AVR ___ 
admitted for endocarditis.

# Endocarditis with severe aortic regurgitation
The patient was seen in outpatient echo clinic for a TTE, and 
noticed to have possible aortic root abscess. She had a blood 
culture which initially grew coag. neg staph and strep viridans 
___. She was sent to the emergency room. 
The patient was started on vancomycin/gentamicin. She initially 
developped a minor arm rash and itch to Vancomycin, but did not 
show reaction on subsequent administration. Repeat TEE revealed 
a large circumferential aortic root clear space. When compared 
to the previous TEE obtained from ___ (___), it was 
felt that this could represent remnants of prior aortic sinus 
dilatation, although an annular abscess could not be excluded. 
Over the course of the hospitalisation, the patient remained 
afebrile and showed no signs of sepsis. There were no signs of 
embolic phenomena on physical examination or on CT imaging of 
the chest/abdomen/pelvis and MRI/MRA of the brain. Her 
neurological examination remained stable. Her EKG remained at 
baseline. On ___, the patient suddenly developed 
hypotension and altered mental status. Repeat echo did not 
reveal any changes. Her condition rapidly improved post 
hydration. She remained asymptomatic after that.
She was seen by both cardiac surgery and infectious disease. 
Because the echo changes were felt to be chronic, emergent 
surgery was not deemed necessary. She had full pre-surgery 
work-up and will be discharged home with a ___ access for 
long-term antiobics. Follow-up appointments will be arranged 
with CT surgery and ID.

# Neurological symptoms  
During the admission, the patient was noted to have ataxia on 
the left upper extremities, indicating possible cerebellar 
involvement. In the context of a suspected emboli, a MRI/MRA of 
the head was ordered to rule out emboli. A 3 mm aneurysm on the 
trifurcation of the MCA was found. Neurosurgery was consulted 
and a CTA was ordered to better assess the morphology of the 
aneurysm. The conclusion from the neurosurgical team was that 
this was an incidental berry aneurysm. Follow-up imaging and 
neurosurgical appointments have been arranged.

years ago. She will need follow-up from her primary care 
physician.

sarcoidosis. She will need outpatient workup and follow-up from 
her primary care physician.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with AVR and endocarditis with blood cx growing coag neg 
Staph and Strep viridans, on IV PCN and gent, now presents with 
___.
.
#. ___: The patient presented with acute elevation in creatinine 
after about 3 weeks IV gentamycin. The most likely cause was ATN 
from gentamycin. Alternative causes included AIN (urine eos 
neg), pre-renal, and obstructive. Urine electrolytes were not 
consistent with pre-renal, and Cr did not improve with 2 L IVF. 
UA and culture was negative. Urine sediment was unremarkable. In 
setting of endocarditis, immune complex deposition was 
considered, but serum complement levels were wnl.
Gentamycin level at admission was subtherapeutic, and further 
doses were held. All nephrotoxic meds were held, including 
patient's home HCTZ. The patient continued to make adequate 
urine, but creatinine continued to rise. Renal consult was 
called. Renal U/S ruled out hydronephrosis. On day five of 
admission Crt peaked at 3.5 before the trending down. Pt was 
discharged with close follow up with her PCP. Nephrology did not 
feel that she needed to be followed by nephrology if her Crt 
continued to trend down. Nephrology believes her renal function 
should return to baseline. 
.
#. AV endocarditis: Patient had TTE showing perivalvular leak 
and positive blood cx in ___ for 2 strains of Strep viridans, 1 
intermediately resistant to PCN, as well as Coag Neg Staph 
(question if contaminant). Patient was D/Ced with 4 week course 
IV PCN/Gent at home. TEE at that time showed aortic annular 
abscess and increased AR. On admission, gentamycin was held. ID 
was consulted and the patient was started on vancomycin, dosed 
by levels. CRP and ESR were wnl and will be monitored. TEE was 
repeated on ___ and showed no significant change from prior. 
The patient is being followed by CT surgery for replacement AVR. 
The patient remained afebrile and all blood cx negative during 
course. No chest pain, SOB or hemodynamic changes were seen to 
suggest worsening AR. Repeat TEE did not show aortic annular 
abscess and no aortic valve vegitations, with stable aortic 
regurgitation. Pt will be followed closely by cardiology and CT 
surgery. 
.
#. cerebral aneurysm: found incidentally on last admission, 
neurosurgery is following as outpatient, and repeat MRI is 
scheduled in ___.
.
#. muscle pain: patient takes Chlorzoxazone at home, was treated 
with Flexeril in hospital.
.
#. HTN: home dose HCTZ was held for ___. The patient remained 
normotensive and no antihypertensives were required during 
course. The patient should monitor her blood pressure and PCP 
can consider ___ if elevated as outpatient.
.
#. anxiety/depression: cont home meds.
.

both inside and outside of the ear.  The ear itself is very 
painful and any movement causes great discomfort.  She has pain 
extending from her ear down her jaw making it painful for her to 
open her mouth.  She reports headache associated with ear pain, 
but denies visual changes, dizziness, fevers, chills.  She had 
one episode of vertigo this morning with some prolonged standing 
while showering.

manipulation, recent illness, sick contacts.

left ear and over part of your face and was causing you severe

evaluated by the ear-nose-throat doctors who did not think you 
needed any further intervention.  They agreed that this was most 
likely a bacterial ear infection.

to put in your left ear.

full course, even if you feel better before finishing the

Discharge Instructions:
___ your pain medicine as prescribed.
oExercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
oIncrease your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
oUnless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
oClearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
oContinue Sinus Precautions for an additional two weeks.  This 
means, no use of straws, forceful blowing of your nose, or use 
of your incentive spirometer. 
oIf you have been discharged on Prednisone, take it daily as 
prescribed.  
oIf you are required to take Prednisone, an oral steroid, make 
sure you are taking a medication to protect your stomach 
(Prilosec, Protonix, or Pepcid), as this medication can cause 
stomach irritation.  Prednisone should also be taken with a 
glass of milk or with a meal. 

CALL YOUR DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

oNew onset of tremors or seizures.
oAny confusion or change in mental status. 
oAny numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
oPain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
oAny signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
oIt is normal for feel nasal fullness for a few days after 
surgery, but if you begin to experience drainage or salty taste 
at the back of your throat, that resembles a dripping 
sensation, or persistent, clear fluid that drains from your nose 
that was not present when you were sent home, please call. 
oFever greater than or equal to 101° F.
oIf you notice your urine output to be increasing, and/or 
excessive, and you are unable to quench your thirst, please call 
your endocrinologist. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

# Sepsis: Likely secondary to community acquired pneumonia. 
Patient meeting SIRS criteria secondary to tachycardia, 
leukocytosis and source of infection likely being PNA. Also had 
lactate elevation. Patient given ceftriaxone and levofloxacin in 
the ED. Initially broadened to vanco, cefepime, and azithro 
given sepsis and immunosuppression. The patient was given 1L IVF 
in the ED and his lactate improved. Likely etiology of pneumonia 
is post-viral bacterial infection vs. ongoing viral pneumonia.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo male with multiple medical problems presents with b/l eye 
swelling.
.
1) Eye swelling/Transient decreased visual acuity
Initially there was a question of cellulitis.  He was treated 
with Unasyn.  However, the CT scan did not show any evidence of 
cellulitis.  The folliwing day, the patient's swelling had 
resolved.  Optho saw the patient and appreciated dilated 
ophtalmic veins.  They recommended discontinuing antibiotics and 
having the patient follow up in clinic.  Given the possibility 
of thrombus of fistulous communication causing the dilated 
veins, an MRI of the orbits was performed (results as above).  
This showed dilated opthalmic veins with likely thrombus.  There 
is still a possibility of a carotid-cavernous fistula.  The test 
of choice to assess this would be an angiogram.  Opthalomology 
can arrange for this once the patient is seen in clinic (it is 
not an urgent or emergent study per the consult team).  On 
discharge, the patient's vision had returned back to baseline.
.
2) URI vs. Pneumonia
The patient had a cough and there was question of pneumonia on 
CXR.  He only had low-grade temps initially and after that was 
afebrile.  WBC count was WNL.  He was given a total 5-day course 
of high dose Levaquin (750mg) to cover for a possible pneumonia. 
 He should have a follow up chest x-ray in 6 weeks to ensure 
resolution.
.
3) CIDP  
Was continued on steroid therapy.  Should follow up with 
neurology.  
.  
4) DM-2
Was kept on glyburide and sliding scale insulin.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female history of 
alcohol abuse and recent hepatitis A infection (___), 
schizoaffective disorder, and recent diagnosis of alcoholic 
hepatitis, who presented to ___ as a transfer from ___ 
with alcoholic hepatitis. She subsequently developed severe ARDS 
and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring paralysis, septic 
shock requiring vasopressors, and acute renal failure requiring 
CRRT. She improved significantly from these illnesses, though 
her liver disease remained significant with a MELD-Na of 38. She 
had also developed toxic-metabolic encephalopathy in the setting 
of her prolonged critical illness. She fell on ___ with 
resultant subdural hematoma. She had rapid deterioration of her 
neurologic exam, with a lack of brain stem reflexes by the time 
of neurosurgical intervention. She underwent craniotomy and 
evacuation of subdural hematoma, but her neurologic exam 
remained poor despite this. She ultimately progressed to brain 
death and died on ___.

==============
ACUTE ISSUES
==============

# Hypoxemic respiratory failure in the setting of ARDS: The 
patient triggered for hypoxemia and tachypnea on the medicine 
service on ___, and was subsequently transferred to the MICU, 
where she was intubated and sedated. Initial CXR consistent with 
ARDS, and as a result the patient was started on lung-protective 
ventilation. An esophageal balloon was placed to determine ideal 
PEEP settings. Neuromuscular blockade was used for 48 hrs for 
severe ARDS. She was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. A 
mini-BAL was performed which was sterile. The patient was 
extubated on ___ following improvement in mental status and 
respiratory mechanics. She was weaned to room air following 
extubation.

# Septic Shock: Patient was hypotensive requiring placement of 
central venous cathether with pressor infusion. She was treated 
with broad spectrum antibiotics and her vasopressor requirement 
ultimately resolved.
 
#Acute renal failure: Patient became anuric while in the MICU, 
secondary to acute tubular necrosis in the setting of shock. 
Nephrology was consulted, and the patient was initiated on CVVH 
after placement of dialysis catheter. CVVH was discontinued on 
___ when the patient was extubated, with plan to pursue 
intermittent hemodialysis. The patient tolerated a session of 
intermittent hemodialysis well on ___. 

# Alcoholic Hepatitis: MDF on admission was ___, Child ___ C. 
Acetaminophen, viral hepatitis labs negative, autoimmune 
hepatitis titers within normal limits. EGD was performed without 
evidence of varices. Steroids were held upon admission and were 
not started upon MICU transfer out of concern for infection / 
sepsis. Nutrition was consulted, and the patient was maintained 
on tube feeds while intubated and sedated. She was continued on 
thiamine and multivitamin, with rifaximin and lactulose to 
prevent hepatic encephalopathy. She had significant 
leukocytosis, likely due to alcoholic hepatitis, as her cultures 
were all negative.

# Fall Resulting in Subdural Hematoma: Patient attempted to exit 
bed in the late afternoon on ___ without assistance, resulting 
in a fall. Patient was found down at 17:20 by nursing, 
apparently struck the front of her face, and was noted to have 
bleeding from her upper lip and nose (Dobhoff had been displaced 
during the fall). Upon initial neurologic examination, patient 
was found to be neurologically intact, including cranial nerve 
and strength examination. Obvious injuries included hematomas on 
her bilateral knees and bleeding from the upper lip. The family 
was informed of the initial event. She was continuously observed 
and approximately 30 minutes later was noted to be unresponsive 
to verbal or tactile stimuli. Pupils were 4mm and reactive 
bilaterally at that time. A stat non-contrast head CT was 
ordered which demonstrated a large subdural hematoma with 
midline shift. The patient was intubated for airway protection 
and neurosurgery was urgently consulted. The patient was 
administered 2 units of FFP and 10mg IV vitamin K. Prior to 
surgery, her neurologic exam was notable for fixed and dilated 
pupils, and her family was counseled that surgery was unlikely 
to meaningfully improve her neurologic exam. The patient 
underwent R-sided craniotomy, with evacuation of subdural. 
Midline shift persisted post-operatively, and pupils remained 
fixed. A family meeting was held on ___ with discussion of the 
prior day's events, surgical outcome, and grim prognosis. The 
patient's family expressed wishes to continue with supportive 
therapy, and as a result patient was transfused pRBCs for 
ongoing bleeding at the site of the craniotomy, as well as an 
additional 5mg IV vitamin K for coagulopathy. By the afternoon 
of ___, physical examination was concerning for lack of 
brainstem reflexes, though she intermittently breathed above the 
ventilator. Multiple family meetings were held to explain the 
grave prognosis and elicit concerns. On ___, pt lacked all 
brainstem reflexes. A breath death scan was performed on ___ 
which was demonstrated no cerebral blood flow. An apnea test was 
consistent with brain death. The patient was terminally 
extubated on ___ at 2300, with time of death pronounced on 
2334. Condolences were offered to the patient's family, who were 
at bedside at the time death was pronounced.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service on 
___ following a trauma activation for a motor vehicle 
collision. She was hemodynamically stable in the trauma bay, and 
imaging was obtained of head, cspine, torso, right shoulder and 
left ankle. This revealed a small pericardial effusion, right 
anterior neck/chest/shoulder/abdomen hematoma, as well as a left 
Weber A fibula fracture. 

She was evaluated by Orthopedic Surgery who recommended 
non-operative management after fracture was demonstrated to be 
stable on gravity stress x-ray. They recommended weight bearing 
as tolerated with a short air cast boot. This was fitted 
___, and she was evaluated by physical therapy who cleared 
her for discharge home. 

She was monitored and remained hemodynamically stable throughout 
her hospital stay. Her repeat CBCs were stable, and her pain was 
managed with oral pain medications and lidocaine patch. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Brief Hospital Course:
REASON FOR HOSPITALIZATION: 
___ M with recent tooth implant now with recurrent sinus 
infections who is presenting from OSH with persistent fevers & 
chills despite antibiotics which was found to be due to 
maxillary osteomyelitis.

ACUTE DIAGNOSES:

# Tooth Implant Infection: Pt was initially treated with IV 
vancomycin, ciprofloaxacin, flagyl. OFMS was consulted and 
recommended removing the implant; the patient went to the OR on 
___ for tooth implant extraction, debridement, & bone 
biopsy.  Pt will follow up with OFMS as outpatient. 

# Maxillary Osteomyelitis: Treated with antibiotics as above.  
Given the question of positive blood cultures at OSH & presumed 
dental source on admission, a TTE was obtained which ruled out 
infective endocarditis. The patient's bone biopsy was consistent 
with osteomyelitis. The patient was followed by ID while 
hospitalized. Preliminary bone biopsy grew GPC & GNRs which were 
ultimately found to be micrococcus & stomatococcus, GPRs, 
Viridans strep. ID recommended disharging the patient on IV 
vancomycin & PO moxifloxacin for 6 weeks.. The patient's OSH 
PICC was removed (tip culture was negative) on admission; a new 
PICC was placed. His blood cultures were remained negative.

# Recurrent Maxillary Sinusitis:  Most likely thought to be due 
recurrent seeding from tooth implant infection and maxillary 
osteomyelitis.  ENT was consulted and recommended obtaining CT 
sinuses/maxilla.  The patient will follow up with ___ ENT.  Pt 
also has hypomobility of R true vocal cord, which will also be 
addressed on an outpatient basis.  

# Diarrhea: Pt noted to have diarrhea after initiation of IV 
antibiotcs.  C. Diff was checked & was negative.  Thought to be 
antibiotic-associated diarrhea.  

# Peripheral Thrombophlebitis: Pt noted to develop indurated, 
erythematous area around one of his IV sites.  Warm packs were 
applied with resolution of symptoms. 

CHRONIC DIAGNOSES:
# HTN: Pt was continued on norvasc, HCTZ, labetalol.

# HLD: Continued atorvastatin.

# Anxiety: Continued xanax.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
# Follow Up: The patient will follow up with ENT, oral surgery, 
& infectious disease

# Lab Draws: The patient will have weekly lab draws to monitor 
CBC, Chem 10, LFTs, vanco trough for 6 weeks while on 
vancomycin.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

You were admitted to ___ after 
you were found to have a perforated appendix with a collection 
on CT scan. You were given bowel rest, IV antibiotics, and 
monitored. Your pain improved, and your white blood cell count ( 
a marker of infection) improved to normal levels. You are now 
ready to be discharged home to continue your recovery. You will 
have a colonoscopy in six weeks, and then follow up with the 
Acute Care Surgery clinic to determine when to take out your 
appendix, after the inflammation is resolved. 

 ACTIVITY:
- Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
 
- You may climb stairs, and you should continue to walk several 
times a day.  
 
- You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
 
- You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
 
- Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first.
 
- You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you 
otherwise.
 

 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
 
- You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
 
- You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during the endoscopy.
 

 
YOUR BOWELS:
 
- Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as 
oxycodone. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
 
- If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.
  
You should schedule a colonoscopy for 6 weeks from now. You 
should follow up with the Acute Care Surgery clinic after your 
colonoscopy, to discuss surgery to remove your appendix. You may 
discuss repair of your umbilical hernia at this appointment. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
 You should take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, not to 
exceed 3000mg per day. You have not needed the oxycodone. 
- Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
If you experience any of the folloiwng, please contact your 
surgeon:
 
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
- Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just 
as you did before, unless you have been told differently.
- If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not 
to take, please call your surgeon. 

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care. We hope 
you have a speedy return to your normal life. 

- Your ___ care team

 
Followup Instructions:

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
  
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of confusion and 
difficulty speaking resulting from an ACUTE left sided bleed in 
your brain. We have imaged your brain with CT and found you to 
have a new left sided bleed which was stable throughout your 
admission. We compared it to your previous MRI and think this is 
due to a combination of your blood pressure and accumulation of 
protein plaques in the brain.  

The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all 
the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being 
deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of 
symptoms.  

During your admission we performed the following interventions:  
stopped your ibuprofen or any medication that contains the words 
NSAIDs on the label as these can increase your bleeding risk. We 
added a blood pressure medication called propranolol 80mg oral 
daily to control your blood pressure while preventing your 
headaches. You will need follow up with your primary care doctor 
in terms of increasing the dose as needed. We have asked you to 
monitor your blood pressure daily and keep a log to take to your 
PCP. You will need follow up with the neurology department, as 
below. You were seen by physical and occupational therapy who 
recommended outpatient speech therapy. 

Instructions: 
Please take your other medications as prescribed.  
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
- sudden weakness of one side of the body  
- sudden drooping of one side of the face  
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Tumor

Surgery
 You underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your 
brain. 
 Please keep your incision dry until your sutures are removed. 
 You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
 It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
 Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
 We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
 You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
 No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
 If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
 No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
 Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
 You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
 You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
 You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
 You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
 Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
 Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
 Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
 Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
 Nausea and/or vomiting
 Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
 Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
 Seizures
 Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
 Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
 Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
 Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
 Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
 Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ the patient underwent a right mastectomy followed by 
immediate deep inferior epigastric perforator flap breast 
reconstruction. A partial rib resection of the third rib was 
also carried out. The patient tolerated the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received morphine PCA with 
good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to percocet with good pain 
control. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Foley was removed on POD#2. 
Intake and output were closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO cephalexin for discharge home. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. On POD 
#3, patient had a low grade fever so a chest xray and urinalysis 
were both obtained. Chest xray showed small area of opacity over 
right lower lobe, likely atelectasis and urinalysis was pending 
at time of discharge and will be followed up.
.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#4, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  Her right breast incisions were healing well and 
she had 1 JP drain in her right axillary area draining serous 
fluid.  Her lower abdominal incision was CDI with 2 JP drains 
intact draining serous fluid.  She had a large blister wound 
just below her umbilicus that was covered with DSD and had 
Bactroban  applied.

Discharge Instructions:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
 Personal Care:
1. Remove dressings and discard. Dressings may be replaced as 
needed. Use tape sparingly.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with hydrogen peroxide.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.
5. DO NOT wear a bra for 3 weeks. You may wear a camisole for 
comfort as desired.
6. You may shower daily with assistance as needed.
7. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___ 
days.
8. No pressure on your chest or abdomen
9. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.  Avoid caffeine and 
chocolate.
2. DO NOT drive for 3 weeks.
3. Keep hips flexed at all times for 1 week, and then gradually 
stand upright as tolerated.
4. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery.
5. Please perform the occupational therapy exercises as 
instructed.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered .
2. Take Aspirin, 120 mg by mouth once daily, for 30 days after 
surgery.
3. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength 
Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging.  Please note 
that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient 
so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old ___ male with a pmh of 
frontotemporal dementia, parkinsonism, paranoid schizophrenia, 
GERD, and chronic Hep C who presented from ___ with 
recurrent fevers since ___ without a clear source.
  
# Fever. Currently with a negative work-up. There were several 
concerns. He had a leukocytosis and fever to 103 in the ED, WBCs 
on his UA, with concern for chronic aspiration and a midline 
line IV in place on admission. Blood, lung, and urine were all 
potential sources. He had cultures sent for all three sources 
and had been covered with levo, flagyl, and vanc at his NH. His 
urine culture was negative, sputum grew yeast and respiratory 
flora and his blood cultures were NGTD at discharge. He was 
initially covered broadly with vanc and imipenem out of concern 
for aspiration, but CXR and sputum pointed away from this. He 
was narrowed after 48 hours to Ciprofloxacin and remained 
afebrile. His midline was removed. 

# Hyponatremia. 150 on admission, likely from decrease in PO 
intake, and inability to access free water with increased 
insensible losses. He was given 2L NS in the ED and Repleted 
with D5W at 125cc/hr which corrected his sodium to 143. He was 
able to take fluids PO without coughing. He will need a formal 
speech and swallow evaluation to determine what he will be able 
to take by mouth going forward. 

# Frontotemporal dementia/Parkinsonism. He failed a trial of 
treatment in the past with worsening psychosis on 
antiParkinsonian meds. Currently on bupropion and mirtazapine 
and treating insomnia with lorazepam.

# Somnolence: Unclear etiology during his stay. He had waxing 
and waning and the differential included hypoactive delirium 
complicated by acute illness. Also likely a medication effect. 
He had received metoclopramide standing during admission. This 
was discontinued for somnolence. His psychiatric medications 
were also held for 1 dose and bupropion was halved in dosing to 
37.5mg BID, with mirtazapine and lorazepam being made prn due to 
somnolence. As he continues to clinically improve his 
medications can be uptitrated as he tolerates to his regular 
dosing.

.
#FEVER: He has several risk factors as well as a personal 
history of aspiration.  Aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia was 
considered to be the most likely etiology given CT findings of 
bibasilar pulmonary opacity and secretions in trachea. He was 
afebrile and on room air during his hospital course. He was 
treated with levofloxacin and metronidazole (penicillin allergy) 
with good response.  He will be treated for a total of 7 days 
with a completion date of ___.  On date of discharge he was 
afebrile with oxygen saturation in the mid ___ on room air.  
   A bedsite swallow eval was performed and the recommendation 
was to continue with pureed diet with thin liquids, med crush in 
apple sauce and close supervision while eating.  He was 
continued to be placed on aspiration precaution.  U/A was 
negative and blood cxs have been negative to date.  
.
#HYPERNATREMIA: The most likely etiology is hypovolemia in the 
setting of fever and possibly reduced PO intake. He was given 
IVF with normalization of his sodium.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a  with an enlarging 5.0 cm AAA who was admitted 
to the ___ on ___. The 
patient was taken to the endovascular suite and underwent an 
uncomplicated EVAR. For details of the procedure, please see the 
surgeon's operative note. The patient tolerated the procedure 
well without complications and was brought to the 
post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition. After a brief 
stay, the patient was transferred to the vascular surgery floor 
where she remained through the rest of the hospitalization. 

Post-operatively, she did well without any groin swelling. She 
did have some new onset lower back pain which was thought to be 
secondary to a musculoskeletal etiology, as the pain was 
reproducible and responded well to a Lidocaine patch and warm 
compresses. She was also noted to have a WBC of 16 on POD#2, day 
of her discharge, which was attributed to a post-operative 
inflammatory response. She had a negative UA and a 
non-concerning CXR that was performed on POD#2 as well. She felt 
comfortable being discharged home. 

Prior to her discharge, she was able to tolerate a regular diet, 
get out of bed and ambulate without assistance, void without 
issues, and pain was controlled on oral medications alone. We 
monitored her incisions and peripheral pulse status, which 
remained reassuring. She was deemed ready for discharge, and was 
given the appropriate discharge and follow-up instructions.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the ___ 
for endovascular repair of your abdominal aortic aneurysm. You 
tolerated the procedure well and are ready to return home to 
finish your recovery. 

Monitor your groin incisions closely for bleeding or evidence of 
an underlying hematoma. Please see the following instructions 
regarding your discharge.

MEDICATIONS:
 Take Aspirin 81mg (enteric coated) once daily 
 Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you 
to do so. 
 Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
 You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

WHAT TO EXPECT AT HOME:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
 Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
 When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
 You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
 After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
 After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
 No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
* Severe back pain that is not improving
 Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
 Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
 New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
 Bleeding from groin puncture site

FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or 
incision)
 Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for 
transfer to closest Emergency Room. 

Good Luck
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm s/p endovascular abdominal aortic 
repair (EVAR) with acute right hip and back pain.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the Division of Vascular Surgery for 
evaluation and treatment of back and right hip pain in the 
postoperative setting s/p endovascular repair of a 5.0 cm 
infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  You were monitored by a 
multidisciplinary team and treated non-surgically.  A CTA of the 
abdomen and pelvis revealed no concerns with your endo-stent, 
which was without endoleak, hematoma, or pseudoaneurysm.  Please 
follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy and 
uneventful recovery.

Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery - Discharge 
Instructions

MEDICATIONS
Continue Aspirin daily. 
       Continue Pravastatin.
It is very important that you never stop taking aspirin for 
even for a short while - unless the surgeon who repaired your 
aneurysm tells you it is okay to stop.   Do not stop taking 
them, even if another doctor or nurse tells you to, without 
getting an okay from the surgeon who first prescribed them. 
You will be given prescriptions for any new medication started 
during your hospital stay.
okay to take it. 

PAIN MANAGEMENT Recommendations:
 Ibuprofen 400-600 mg TID PRN {OR} topical diclofenac gel to be 
applied to affected areas BID PRN. 
 Lidocaine 5% Patch 1 PTCH TD QPM 
 TraMADol 25 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
 Acetaminophen 650 mg PO/NG TID

ACTIVITY
It is normal to feel weak and tired for six-eight weeks 
post-operatively s/p EVAR. This should get better day by day.   
You may want to have help around the house during this time.
We encourage you to walk regularly. Walking, especially 
outdoors in good weather is the best exercise for circulation.  
Walk short distances at first, even in the house, then do a 
little more each day.
It is okay to climb stairs.  You may need to climb them slowly 
and pause after every few steps. 

DIET
It is normal to have a decreased appetite.  Your appetite will 
return over time.
Follow a well balance, heart-healthy diet, with moderate 
restriction of salt and fat. 
Eat small, frequent meals with nutritious food options (high 
fiber, lean meats, fruits, and vegetables) to maintain your 
strength and to help with wound healing.

BOWEL AND BLADDER FUNCTION
You should be able to pass urine without difficulty.  Call you 
doctor if you have any problems urinating, such as burning, 
pain, bleeding, going too often, or having trouble urinating or 
starting the flow of urine.   Call if you have a decrease in the 
amount of urine. 
You may experience some constipation after surgery because of 
pain medicine and changes in activity.  Increasing fluids and 
fiber in your diet and staying active can help.  To relief 
constipation, you may talk a mild laxative.   Please take to 
your pharmacist for advice about what to take.

somewhat disorganized at times. Cognitive examination notable 
for deficits in short term memory and executive functioning with 
neuroimaging on ___ (CT without contrast) notable for prominence 
of the ventricles and sulci suggestive of involuntional change 
and periventricular and subcortical white matter matter 
hypodensities are nonspecific, but likely reflect sequelae of 
chronic small vessel ischemic disease. 
. 
Given lack of any formal psychiatric history prior to 
approximately ___ years ago with family noting gradual decline 
over the past few years with apparent periods of confusion, 
forgetfulness, paranoia and cognitive examination as noted 
above, etiology of presentation is most likely consistent with 
underlying neurocognitive disorder (likely vascular dementia 
given patient's cardiovascular risk and imaging findings) with 
behavioral disturbances and psychotic and depressive features. 
. 
#. Legal/Safety: Patient admitted to ___ on a ___, upon admission he initially declined to sign a CV, but later 
signed one, which was accepted. Patient was initially placed on 
15 minute checks, but was switched to security CO after he tried 
eloping outside the unit on his way to a diagnostic procedures 
and became agitated and aggressive toward staff requiring 
chemical and physical restraint (see the description of the 
behavioral incident below). Once patient's behavior returned to 
his baseline, he was progressively switched to 5 minue checks 
and ultimately to 15 minute checks by the time of discharge.  
.
#. Neurocognitive disorder with behavioral disturbances and 
psychotic and depressive features: 
For depressive symptoms (predominantly sad mood and 
tearfulness), patient was started on sertraline that was 
uptitrated to 75 mg PO daily by the time of discharge. For 
insomnia, patient received 8 mg PO ramelteon QHS with good 
effect.
After risks and benefits of initiating an atypical antipsychotic 
were discussed with patient and his family, patient was briefly 
trialed on low dose risperidone (0.25-0.5 mg a day) that did not 
appear to be effective in alleviating patient's paranoid 
ideation or behavioral disturbances. Patient was then switched 
to low dose olanzapine (2.5 mg PO QHS and 2.5 mg PO DAILY:PRN 
for severe anxiety/agitation), which resulted in a modest 
improvement in patient's anxiety and paranoid ideation and 
resolution of behavioral disturbances. Patient tolerated 
sertraline, risperidone and ramelteon well and consistently 
denied any side effects.
Benzodiazepines and anticholinergic medications were avoided 
during the admission as much as possible.
.
Patient was encouraged to attend groups and was provided with 
milieu, supportive psychotherapy and psychoeducation. He was 
reluctant about participating in groups at first but by the time 
of discharge went to at least one group a day and made relevant 
contributions to discussions. 
Patient's family was educated about his condition and about the 
benefits of frequent re-orientation and patient being in a 
familiar environment. Patient's family was encouraged to use ___ 
and Senior Services of ___, as well as to take 
patient to a senior ___ in their community for day 
programs.
.
During his hospitalization, patient had one behavioral episode 
that required use of chemical and physical restraints. On ___ 
patient choked on a chicken bone at dinner, and Heimlich 
maneuver was used successfully. Despite the expulsion of the 
bone during the Heimlich maneuver, patient complained of 
continued discomfort in his throat and was taken for a neck 
X-ray. On his way to radiology, patient pushed the staff member 
accompanying him and tried eloping. He was agitated and 
physically aggressive toward staff members who came to escort 
him back to the unit, and chemical and physical restraints had 
to be used. Patient was not injured in the process and tolerated 
the restraints well. Physical restraint was discontinued as soon 
as patient was no longer danger to self or others, and patient 
was placed on security CO. Once patient's behavior returned to 
his baseline, he was progressively switched to 5 minute checks 
and ultimately to 15 minute checks by the time of discharge.
.
By discharge, patient's mood has improved with less sadness and 
lability, his anxiety and paranoid ideation became less frequent 
and more tolerable (with patient being able to cope with them 
without acting out), and patient was notably future-oriented 
looking forward to spend time with his grandchildren.
.
#. Medical:
Patient has a history of hypertension, trigeminal neuralgia, 
glaucoma, diet controlled type II diabetes mellitus and 
subclinical hypothyroidism. Patient's home medication regimens 
were continued as following:
- for hypertension, patient was continued on hydrochlorothiazide 
12.5 mg PO daily, atenolol 25 mg PO daily and lisinopril 40 mg 
PO daily;
- for trigeminal neuralgia, patient was continued on Trileptal 
300 mg PO BID;
- for glaucoma, patient was continued on timolol maleate 0.5% 1 
drop both eyes daily.
Patient's type II diabetes mellitus continued being controlled 
by diet with HgbA1c of 6.0 on ___ and daily glucose finger 
sticks in the 97-206 range.
.
Regarding the choking on chicken bone incident: portable neck 
X-ray was negative for foreign bodies, and fiberoptic 
examination of patient's throat did not reveal any foreign 
bodies, masses or significant lesions other than some posterior 
inflammation suggestive of GERD. Patient received viscous 
lidocaine for residual throat pain and was started on omeprazole 
20 mg PO QPM for GERD.

ACTIVE ISSUES
=============
# Chest pain with troponin elevation: Most concerning for ACS, 
though EKG without acute ischemic changes, TTE without regional 
wall motion abnormality, chest pain atypical nature, and pt's 
young age makes this very unlikely. Viral myocarditis thought to 
be most likely etiology. Demand ischemia also possible, though 
without a very clear inciting event. Initially felt to have 
global hypokinesia on a bedside TTE, but a formal TTE on ___ 
with normal EF and no regional wall motion abnormalities. Also 
considered cardiomyopathies from other etiologies, such as 
familial (no known h/o CM), infectious (pt with recent viral vs 
bacterial gastroenteritis), toxic (pt denies heavy EtOH use or 
other drugs), infiltrative (amyloid, sarcoid, hemochromatosis, 
tumor), autoimmune (polymyositis, SLE, scleroderma, RA, PAN, 
eosinophilic, giant cell), Takotsubo (no apical ballooning), 
ARVC. Pt not tachycardic. Also can consider metabolic causes 
(hypothyroid, acromegaly, pheo, OSA, thiamine, selenium or 
carnitine defic). TSH wnl. HAV, HBVsAg, HCV negative. HBV 
non-immune. IgM wnl. HIV neg. A1c 5.6%. Troponin peaked at 0.44, 
CK-MB also peaked at 17 on ___ ___. Transferrin sat ~9%, low 
concern for hemochromatosis. Elevated ___ (460) on a non-fasting 
panel, and unchanged from prior known levels. Cholesterol panel 
otherwise wnl. Pt was kept on a heparin gtt until formal TTE 
most likely ruled out ischemic etiology. Pt was on ASA 81, 
metoprolol, and atorvastatin through his stay and was 
discontinued at discharge. Pt needs to receive cardiac MRI as 
outpatient

# Elevated D-dimer: Most likely representation of acute phase 
reactant in setting of viral illness. Patient without any 
resting tachycardia, O2 requirement, or dyspnea at any point 
during admission to suggest PE. PERC score 0. 

# Fatty steatosis with RUQ TTP: On admission, LFTs normal, 
slightly increased lipase. Fatty steatosis seen on RUQ 
ultrasound in ED. NAFLD diagnosis requires imaging, exclusion of 
significant EtOH consumption, and exclusion of other causes of 
hepatic steatosis. HAV, HBVsAg, HCV negative. Low concern for 
hemochromatosis with Transferrin sat 9%. High ___ at 460 (but 
non-fasting and unchanged from prior outpatient levels). 
Cholesterol levels otherwise wnl. Pt with mild TTP on RUQ at 
time of discharge, but improved from admission, and would 
recommend outpatient follow up. Would also recommend decreasing 
alcohol use and increasing exercise.

***please keep track of pain pills and narcotics used on the 
provided Pain Pill Log (orange sheet) over the week and return 
the log sheet at your follow up appointment. Remember to also

you to follow up..

-Please also reference the additional handout provided by your 
urologist with instructions and information about your surgery 
and post-operative plan of care.

-Please also reference the instructions provided by nursing on 
Foley catheter care, hygiene and waste elimination. 

-ALWAYS follow-up with your referring provider ___ your PCP 
to discuss and review your post-operative course and 
medications.  Any NEW medications should also be reviewed with 
your pharmacist.

-Resume your pre-admission medications except as noted AND you 
note that you NO longer need to take medications that shrink 
your prostate (Hytrin, Avodart, Flomax, etc.)

-You may take ibuprofen and the prescribed narcotic together for 
pain control. FIRST, use Tylenol and Ibuprofen.  Add the 
prescribed narcotic (examples: Oxycodone, Dilaudid, 
Hydromorphone) for break through pain that is >4 on the pain 
scale.

-The maximum dose of Tylenol (ACETAMINOPHEN) is 3- 4 grams (from 
ALL sources) PER DAY.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. If you develop 
stomach pain or note black stool, stop the Ibuprofen.  Ibuprofen 
works best when taken around the clock.

-For your safety and the safety of others; PLEASE DO NOT drive, 
operate dangerous machinery, or consume alcohol while taking 
narcotic pain medications. 

-Do NOT drive while Foley catheter is in place.

-AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up. Generally about 
FOUR weeks. Light household chores are generally ok.  Do not 
vacuum. 

-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener ___ a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be health care spending account reimbursable. 

-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation. 

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks

-If you had a drain removed from your abdomen, bandage strips 
called steristrips have been applied to close the wound. Allow 
these bandage strips to fall off on their own ___ days).  
PLEASE REMOVE any remaining dressings w/ gauze within 2 days of 
discharge.  You may get the steristrips wet.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check and Foley removal. DO NOT 
allow anyone that is outside of the urology team remove your 
Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only 
for short-term when leaving the house, etc.

-Take prescribed antibiotic for Foley catheter removal as 
directed

began on ___ when he presented with hematuria.

40 pounds over 2 months and was having fevers and chills. A

___ which showed a heterogeneous nodular infiltration of
the left kidney measuring 8.6 x 8.8 cm with no evidence of
obstruction. He was subsequently referred to urology with
repeat CT revealing a 9-cm solid heterogeneously enhancing
mass arising from the posterior aspect of the upper pole of
the left kidney, most compatible with renal cell carcinoma.

seen. A bone scan on ___ was negative. He underwent an
open radical nephrectomy on ___ with a final report
revealing an 8.5 x 6 x 6 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma,
stage Pt2n0mX ___ grade IV. As he was recovering from
surgery, he developed gradually worsening pain radiating down
his right leg, beginning in the right hip. A MRI was obtained
showing a lytic lesion at the right sacral ala. It appears
that this lesion was on retrospect seen in his previous CT
scans. He was seen by Dr. ___ at ___ who referred him to us for potential high-
dose IL-2 therapy. Given his single-sided presumed metastasis
and stability of this lesion on follow-up CT, he underwent CT-
guided bone biopsy on ___ with pathology confirming
metastatic renal cell carcinoma. He passed eligibility

central line placement to begin therapy. His admission weight

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old man admitted to ___ on ___ 
with metastatic renal cell carcinoma s/p L4-S1 fusion with 
partial sacrectomy and sacro-iliac screw placement in ___ followed by XRT, complicated by ___ surgical site 
infection and right iliac bone pathologic fracture, now 
presenting with altered mental status, acute kidney injury, and 
further progression of his metastatic RCC.

An MRI of lumber spine showed extension of soft tissue mass into 
spinal canal into the spinal canal. It did not show any 
significant findings within the thoracic or cervical spine. A 
head MRI showed possible evidence of cancer spread -> ? 
meningioma vs mets. 

The team was hesitant to pursue an LP given the location of his 
abscess. It was discussed thoroughly with the interventional 
radiology team and they did not feel that there was a safe 
window to pursue an LP, and also were not comfortable attempting 
a cervical level spinal tap. Given the concern for 
leptomeningeal spread, and the inconclusive MRI, the team 
decided to pursue an LP above the level of abscess. An LP was 
completed at the L2-L3 level which showed total protein of 199*, 
but no signs of infection. 

It is difficult to say whether or not the intracranial lesion in 
the patient's brain is benign versus mets without previous 
studies to compare. The CSF studies suggest leptomeningeal 
spread with such a high protein level; however, we will need to 
wait for flow cytometry to be completed to know for sure.

The patient's calcium level was elevated with a low phosphorus. 
His PTH was low at only 8. Our thoughts are an ectopic source of 
PTHrP causing the hypercalcemia. This is a sendout lab and was 
pending at the time of discharge. To mention, ectopic PTHrP has 
been found in up to 15% of ___ patients. The patient received 
IVFs throughout his stay, and also dose of IV pamidronate. He 
was also started on calcitonin briefly to assist in bringing 
down his calcium levels. 

It was decided to not send him home on cacitonin, but the 
patient will need close followup with his PCP this week to have 
it rechecked. The patient will continue his course of nafcillin 
for his lumbar abscess at home. He has several appointments to 
be scheduled after his discharge.

Brief Hospital Course:

carcinoma s/p XRT and chemotherapy ___, and right temporal lobe

#DKA
#Diabetes Mellitus
ED labs demonstrated anion gap metabolic acidosis with 
respiratory compensation. UA at OSH showed ketones in urine. 
These data are consistent with DKA. She has no known history of 
diabetes, meaning this is the initial presentation. Patient was 
monitored with q1 blood glucose levels, treated with insulin 
drip, IVF and potassium repletion per DKA protocol. Once blood 
glucose 140-180 x4 hours patient was transitioned to SC insulin 
and called out to floors. Hb A1C of 16.3. Per endocrinology, her 
apparently abrupt presentation with previously normal blood 
glucose values raise possibility of autoimmune component. She 
may be at increased risk given personal history of alopecia, and 
hypothyroidism. Anti-GAD and anti-insulin AB pending. Patient 
was provided with diabetes education and expressed 
understanding. Patient has ___ that will review diabetes 
education. ___ to discuss exercise and sick plans. Patient 
discharged on the following regimen: 
- Lantus to 60 units with breakfast for basal insulin.
- Standing mealtime Humalog 18 units breakfast, lunch, and 
dinner. 
- No corrective scale until follow up.

___ on ___ AT 3:00 ___.

overlying eschar (sloughed off during hospitalization) without 
surrounding inflammation. HSV/HZV was negative. Small amount of

differential also includes ependymoma and exophytic intra-axial

urgent neurosurgery evaluation per outpatient oncologist who

General Instructions

Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to. 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female smoker with HTN who was 
admitted to the Neurology stroke service with a stroke.

# ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE:
She presented with left sided weakness and sensory changes 
secondary to an acute ischemic stroke in the right hemisphere in 
the setting of a right ICA occlusion. Additionally, imaging of 
her brain is suggestive of left-sided ___ placing her at 
increased risk of vascular insult in the future. She had 
position dependent symptoms while in the hospital and had 
additional watershed infarct in the right internal carotid 
artery territory, requiring transfer to the ICU and pressors to 
increase cerebral perfusion (see below). She was ultimately 
weaned off the pressors, slowly weaned off bedrest, and 
ultimately did well. She was started on midodrine to promote 
cerebral perfusion. She was started on dual antiplatelet therapy 
with aspirin and Plavix given her significant intracranial 
atherosclerosis; she will take both for three months then d/c 
Plavix but take ASA indefinitely. Etiology of her carotid 
occlusion is presumed atherosclerosis - no dissection was seen 
and no cardioembolic source was found. The DDx also includes 
vasculopathy but she had no elevation of ESR and CRP to support 
vasculitis diagnosis and normal renal artery u/s speaks against 
fibromuscluar dysplasia. 

# HOSPITAL ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA: She had cough at presentation 
though admission CXR was unremarkable. Later, she developed a 
fever and CXR was repeated which showed a new opacity consistent 
with pneumonia. She was treated for hospital acquired pneumonia 
with Cefepime and Vancomycin (___) and then was narrowed 
to Ceftriaxone (___).

# HYPERLIPIDEMIA: LDL was elevated to 208. She was started on 
atorvastatin.

# ICU COURSE ___
On ___, the pt's husband reported that she had a difficult 
time ambulating to the bathroom in the morning.  Upon exam soon 
after, she was noted to have left sided hemiplegia and left 
sided neglect, so a STAT NCHCT was completed that showed a new 
right ___ hypodensity near the genu of the corpus 
callosum suggestive of a new infarct and repeat brain MRI showed 
extension of her infarcts. As a result, she was transferred to 
the ICU (___) for vasopressor support and close 
monitoring. During this time, ___ was kept flat and pt received 
IVFs and Phenylephrine to increase SBP to prevent flow-dependent 
ischemia. Patient was started on Midodrine for further blood 
pressure control as well as Atorvastatin. She was seen to have 
improved strength in LUE/LLE and ultimately recovered to her 
recent baseline with mild L sided sensory-motor deficit. She was 
weaned off vasopressors and transferred out of ICU. 

___________________________________________________
___________________________________________________
Transitional Issues:
- Began aspirin and Plavix x 3 months. After 3 months, tentative 
plan is to discontinue Plavix and continue ASA indefinitely.
- Began midodrine: BP should be monitored outpatient - patient 
is at risk for supine HTN with this medication
