Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT & PLAN:  ___ year old man with no significant PMH who 
presented with several days of low grade temperatures, 
headaches, shaking chills, and fatigue after a trip to ___ 
one month prior. 
.
#Febrile syndrome: Presentation seems most consistent with a 
viral syndrome.  Initial suspicion for meningitis in the ED and 
patient given ceftriaxone and vancomycin prior to arrival to the 
medical floor (pt refused LP).  Clinical suspicion for menigitis 
was very low by the time of the patient's admission to the 
floor, so antibiotics were discontinued.  Malaria was also 
entertained given prior traveling history and lack of 
prophylaxis, but smears were negative times four.  Pt did not 
receive any pretrip vaccinations.  Time line of presentation 
inconsistent with dengue.  Typhoid fever and yellow fever also 
thought to be less likely.  Full infection workup, including 
blood cultures, urine analysis, chest radiograph, liver function 
tests, and infectious labs - including viral hepatitis 
(A,C,D,E), EBv, toxo, CMV - were all negative.  With supportive 
care and fluid, the patient's fevers resolved and  symptoms 
significantly improved by hospital day three.  Patient was 
discharged home with PCP follow up.
.
#Tachycardia: On admission patient was tachycardic to the 120s 
which responded well to IV fluid boluses.  EKG consistent with 
sinus tachycardia.  Differential for tachycardia included fever, 
infectious process, anxiety, and hyperthyroidism.  TSH was sent 
which came back as 0.031 with T4 of 7.9 which suggested 
subcllinical hyperthyrodism for which patient will follow up 
with his PCP for further management.  On the day of discharge 
patient's heart rate had decreased to normal ranges of ___. 
.
Transition of care:
Pending Labs: Blood Cultures with no growth to date.
Patient will follow up with his PCP on ___ for evaluation 
of any remaining symptoms he may have as well as for management 
of his subclinical hyperthyrodism.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing sing incision 
laparoscopic right partial nephrectomy. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic 
prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the 
PACU in stable condition.  On POD0, pain was well controlled on 
PCA, hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, and provided with 
pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, 
the patient ambulated, restarted on home medications, basic 
metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked, pain 
control was transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was 
advanced to a clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and 
urethral catheter (foley) were removed without difficulty and 
diet was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital 
course was relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged 
in stable condition, eating well, ambulating independently, 
voiding without difficulty, and with pain control on oral 
analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with 
no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The patient was 
given explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. 
___ in 3 weeks.

Dear Dr ___
You were admitted for an autologous stem cell transplant. You 
had a fever and Strep viridans sepsis during your neutropenic 
phase. You were placed on antibiotics for your fever spikes and 
your fevers resolved. You also developed nausea, diarrhea and 
loss of appetite while you were admitted. These are common side 
effects after transplant and your symptoms continue to improve.

You will need to continue IV antibiotics for a total course of 
14 days (completing ___.

Please take your temperature twice a day, and call us if it goes 
above 100.4.  Please be sure to drink at least 2L (64oz) of 
fluid daily. Call if you are unable to do so, or if you have 
worsening nausea or watery stools.
It has been a pleasure taking care of you.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o typically healthy female with a history 
of asthma who initially presented to ___ on ___ with fever, 
malaise, and aches who now represents with ongoing fevers, ___ 
weakness and bilateral knee effusions.

# Fever with polyarticular arthritis: Patient presented with 
recurrent fevers and bilateral knee effusions with associated 
decrease in range of motion and weakness in her lower 
extremities. The differential for this was broad. Could be 
related to viral illness (e.g. parvovirus), bacterial infection 
(patient with high fevers and rigors rising concern for 
bacteremia and ___ positive blood cultures) vs tick-borne 
illness (negative parasite smear) vs. malignancy (in the setting 
of retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy) vs. secondary to 
rheumatologic process. Arthrocentesis performed in the ___ 
showed right knee with 40,000 WBC and 16,000 RBC and left knee 
with 32,000 WBC and 2200 RBC. Though this was not quite in range 
for septic arthritis, it was felt to be possible since she did 
reiceve one dose ceftriaxone at ___ before arhtrocentesis 
was performed in ___. Due to suspicious for septic 
arthritis, she was empirically covered with vancomycin and 
ceftriaxone from ___ while awaiting culture data. Her 
arthrocentesis gram stain and culture remains negative, however, 
and ___ blood cultures positive from ___ with 
coagulase-negative staphylococcus, which was felt to represent 
contamination. Due to unusual presentation of bilateral joint 
effusions concerning for spetic arthritis, she underwent TTE to 
rule out endocarditis; however this showed no vegetations. She 
was also seen by Rheumatology consult. Multiple lab tests for 
Rheumatologic work-up were sent (e.g. ___, anti-dsDNA, 
___, anti-CCP antibody), but none came back positive. 
Infectious Disease consultation recommended discontinuing 
antibotics, which was done on ___. She was afebrile off of 
antibiotics, and range of motion in both knees improved over 
time, as did her strength (of note, CK was WNL). She did have a 
very elevated CRP, however, with low ESR, in conjunction with 
prominent effusions of both knees, which was puzzling to all 
teams in terms of elucidating the etiology of her illness. Her 
effusions and pain limited her mobility, so she worked with 
Physical Therapy to improve her strength and balance. Overall, 
she likely had post-infectious arthritis (inciting source is 
unclear, but her history is notable for a likely 
viral-prodrome); her response was somewhat consistent with 
viral-mediated vs reactive arthritis. She had been afebrile for 
multiple days on discharge, and was not requiring analgesia. She 
was asked to use tylenol and NSAIDs for pain control, and 
follow-up with Rheumatology as an outpatient.

# Rash: Patient presented with a rash consisting of 
erythematous, non-pruritc macules and papules spread over her 
anterior chest and her extensor surfaces, especially on her 
upper thighs. This was felt to be likely a viral exanthem given 
diffuse involvement without pruritus in setting of acute illness 
vs. drug rash in setting of exposure to cephalexin (given 
eosinophilia and improvement once cephalexin was stopped). This 
was not a typical plaque with eczematous rash as can be seen in 
reactive arthritis, or in sun-exposed areas as would be seen in 
lupus. Possibilities also included salmonella rash (light pink, 
over anteiror chest near shoulder), but stool culture was 
negative. On discharge, her rash was resolving and beginning to 
fade.

# Thrombocytopenia: Admitted with placelet count of 118. Likely 
decreased production due to viral illness versus acute 
infection. No splenomegaly on recent imaging. Thin and thick 
smear negative for parasite. No spherocytes or schistocytes on 
smear. Resolved on discharge.

# Normocytic anemia: Patient is a menstruating female, but 
arrived with hemoglobin of 11.6 on admission. Iron studies were 
consistent with anemia of chronic disease, especially given 
ferritin > 90. No evidence of schistocytes on smear. This was 
trended and stable.

# Retroperitoneal Lymphadenopathy: Noted on CT at ___ done on 
___. This was felt to be mild and non-specific. While it is 
rare, hematologic malignancy (lymphoma) can present with 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. Her LDH was normal, and HIV 
negative. Urinalysis showed mildly active sediment. Overall, 
this was felt to be reactive lymphadenopathy in the setting of 
infection. The patient should have repeat imaging done to assess 
for resolution in 3 months, however.

- consider work-up for hypovitaminosis D with PTH, anti-tTG

- 3 months followup CT of the abdomen and pelvis is recommended

- consider MRI to evaluate likely liver hemangioma

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at ___.

You came to the hospital becasue you had fevers, your legs were 
weak, and your knees were swollen. At the hospital, we drained 
fluid from your knees and you felt a little bit better. Our 
doctors examined ___, and we got a chest x-ray which was normal, 
and an x-ray of your thumb. Although we did not find a specific 
culprit behind your symptoms, we believe that your illness was 
caused by an infection that led to what is called a 
"post-infectious arthritis". Your symptoms should continue to 
improve over time. As a result, we are sending you home with a 
prescription for naproxen to help control your pain.

We also found that you are deficient in Vitamin D during this 
hospitalization. We recommend that you take 50,000 units of 
vitamin D once a week, and follow-up with your primary care 
physician regarding this issue.

You were incidentally noted to have enlarged lymph nodes in your 
abdomen, which may have been caused by your recent infection.  
Radiology recommends a repeat CT of your abdomen in 3 months 
time to ensure resolution of these enlarged lymph nodes.  If 
they persist, further workup may need to be done.

We ask that you take your medications, and follow up with your 
providers as below.

We wish you all the best!
-Your ___ Care Team

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the transplant surgery service for 
hydronephrosis and ureteral stricture.
 
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.

General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic 
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Please follow-up 
with your primary care physician.

General Drain Care:
*Please look at the drain site every day for signs of infection 
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
discharge, warmth, and fever).
*Keep the drain capped for now.  Your transplant doctors ___ 
___ if the drain should be connected to a collection bag or 
container.
*If the drain is connected to a collection container, record the 
color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain.  Call the 
surgeon, nurse practitioner, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character.
*You may shower and wash the drain site gently with warm, soapy 
water.  You may also wash with half strength hydrogen peroxide 
followed by saline rinse.
*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.  Place a drain 
sponge for cleanliness.
*Avoid swimming, baths, and hot tubs.  Do not submerge yourself 
in water.
*Attach the drain securely to your body to prevent pulling or 
dislocation.

Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the 
manufacturer of this prosthesis

-Do NOT pull down on implanted bulbs in scrotum unless otherwise 
advised.

-ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.

-over the next several days you may experience some increased 
swelling of your phallus (and scrotum) resembling a semi-rigid 
phallus (semi-erect); this is "normal" from the prosthesis and 
related surgery/edema. This may be accompanied by discoloration 
(ecchymosis) involving the phallus and the scrotum; this too is 
normal and will gradually resolve.

-Please remove the surgical dressing over penis and/or under 
scrotum on post-operative day two: no further wound care is 
needed and you may leave the wound open to air. 

-Please keep your phallus at midline, pointed toward your 
umbilicus, taped in place with protective gauze/pads (if 
necessary) for the next ___ days. Of course you may point it 
downward for voiding.

-Use a jock-supporter/strap or jockey-type briefs or tight, 
tighty-whities to facilitate this; Subsequently you may 
transition to loose fitting briefs or boxer-briefs for 
support--they should be cotton and/or breathable.

-Do NOT use prosthesis for 6 weeks and until explicitly advised 
by your urologist

-Complete a 7 day course of antibiotics as directed 
(Ciprofloxacin/Cephalexin)

-You may shower, but do NOT bathe, swim or otherwise immerse 
your incision.

-Do NOT lift anything heavier than a phone book and no sports, 
vigorous physical activity (including sexual).

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily Tylenol 
dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Do NOT drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do NOT 
operate dangerous machinery. 
For your safety, please do NOT DRIVE FOR ONE WEEK AFTER SURGERY 
or unless otherwise advised. 

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool "softener"- it is NOT a laxative

-Resume your home medications, EXCEPT HOLD NSAIDs (aspirin, and 
ibuprofen containing products such as Advil & Motrin, Excedrin) 
for ONE week or until you see your urologist in follow-up OR you 
are explicitly advised to resume sooner by your PCP, ___ 
or Cardiologist.  DO NOT RESUME medications like VIAGRA, LEVITRA 
or CIALIS.

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on 
routine care and hygiene

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-DO NOT have anyone else other than your Surgeon or your 
surgeon's representative remove your Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only 
for short-term periods for when leaving the house.

-Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your safety)

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
 You were hospitalized due to symptoms of left hand and face 
numbness resulting from a SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE, a condition 
in which a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the 
brain ruptures preventing adequate blood flow to portions of the 
brain. We think this is due to AMYLOID ANGIOPATHY, a condition 
where abnormal protein deposits in the blood vessels. The brain 
is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other 
parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived 
of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. Your 
EEG did not show any evidence of seizures. 
 Because these events can happen again, and can potentially 
leave permanent deficits, we need to do everything we can to 
prevent them. You will need strict management of your blood 
pressure. Please purchase a blood pressure cuff at your nearest 
pharmacy and start measuring your blood pressure daily.  Your 
systolic blood pressure (the top number) goal is <140. Keep a 
log of your blood pressures and bring them to every appointment. 
 We also recommend a heart healthy diet (low fat, low salt), 
daily exercise, and stress reduction techniques. Please avoid 
lifting more than 10 pounds at a time. You should also avoid 
situations that would put you at high risk for falling and 
causing a bleed. You should stop taking aspirin. You should also 
avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen or 
naproxen (use tylenol instead). Please follow up with your 
primary care physician in the next ___ weeks. Your appointment 
in the stroke clinic is listed below.

It was a pleasure meeting you!
Your ___ Neurology Team

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old morbidly obese right-handed man 
with history of a fib on eliquis, CAD s/p stent, sleep apnea, 
trigeminal neuralgia who presents with acute onset of right eye 
blurriness due to
central retinal artery occlusion. Neurologic exam is notable for 
blurry vision and decreased visual acuity in his right eye. 
Fundoscopy by
ophthalmology showed cherry red spot surrounded by retina
edema/whitening. CT head showed no hemorrhage or large infarct. 
CTA head showed plaque in bilateral ICA. Patient was admitted to 
the stroke service where stroke work up labs were completed and 
he was started on his home medications. He was strongly 
counseled about his weight. Bariatric surgery was discussed and 
patient agreed to meet with a surgeon outpatient for a 
consultation. He has an echo arranged with his outpatient 
cardiologist so no inpatient TTE was conducted.

Transitional Issues:
-continue home medications
- follow up with bariatric surgery outpatient for weight loss
- echo with outpatient cardiologist
- follow up with ophthalmology

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,  
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of right eye visual change 
resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE in the right retinal 
artery, a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and 
nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the 
part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts 
of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its 
blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.  

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
 -high cholesterol
 -Atrial fibrillation
 - obesity

We are very concerned about your weight and would like you to 
lose weight as soon as possible. You may be a candidate for 
bariatric surgery and think you would benefit from a 
consultation with our bariatric surgeons outpatient. You need to 
lose weight in order to prevent future strokes. 

We are changing your medications as follows:  
 -no changes at this time but would like you to continue your 
current medications

Please take your other medications as prescribed. 
 
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  
 Sincerely,  
 Your ___ Neurology Team
